description:
Where do I even start?
The Toro was the yummiest, fattiest piece of tuna I've ever had. It legit felt like it was melting in my mouth.
Meanwhile, the Salmon Tartare had all sorts of textures going on that brought the dish together so well: the softness of the avocado & crab, the fattiness of the salmon, the crunch of the tortilla chip, heavenn!
Finally, my beloved wagyu. Torched to medium-rare (closer to rare) perfection, these highly-marbled pieces of beef were deliciously tender and almost-buttery in flavor.
What can I say? Okane, you never fail to impress me.
author: Kathy Y.

description:
I'm definitely coming back here ! The fish was butter and so fresh. 
Ordered nigiri of amaebe, unagi, uni, hamachi, kampachi. All great quality! Definitely made with love. 
Tried the uni, ikura, salmon skin roll. Ended up getting another one because it was so good! 
Also tried the roppongi which hits the spot. The cucumber wrap made it so good and really complemented the fish. 
And finally the tai chazuke. Salmon, rice, and nori in hot green tea. Super simple yet very nice and tasty.
author: Natasha G.

description:
I ordered the Kaisen Donburi for lunch and this is my favorite work lunch so far. The fish was so fresh and melts. The sushi rice was also nicely done.

It was pretty amazing!

I definitely want to go to their physical location.
author: Serena W.

description:
Yummy, modern sushi spot in Potrero Hill!

Wait/Ambiance: My boyfriend and I didn't have a reservation on a Friday night but we were able to call and get a last minute reservation for 6:30. The restaurant was about half full already and was crowded by the time we left, so definitely try to make a reservation! Really cute, modern decor with pickled veggies in glass jars on the walls, kabuki masks, etc. A cute date night spot in Potrero Hill.

Food: We started off with the Agedashi tofu appetizer, which had a perfect crunch on the outside, silky on the inside, and bathed in a yummy soy/dashi sauce. My boyfriend ordered the sukiyaki, which was a perfect amount of sweet and savory and a good amount of food as well. I ordered the Akihabara roll (unagi, salmon, avocado) which was delicious and super fresh. Definitely recommend!

A new favorite sushi spot in the city. I'll be back!
author: Victoria L.

description:
This place has delicious sushi, the kind where your mouth tastes good after you eat it. I got the California hand roll (very impressive with lots of real crab! Not imitation crab), salmon ikura chazuke (so gooood!! I liked that they used real salmon and the ikura-the orange balls that pop in your mouth- were tasty!), Harajuku roll (the lotus root on top gave it a nice crunch and the salmon was soft and tender), and Ginza roll (the seared hamachi was so tasty and the texture and smell was good).

All of the dishes are perfected so that the combination of ingredients highlight the fish in a really delicious way.
author: Andrea T.

description:
I have to admit that I didn't get the chance to try many fancy sushi restaurants in my life, but this place totally rocks!

Ankimo Nitsuke (3.5/5): Nice and unusual appetizer, if you are a liver fan, go for it.

Oysters with Uni, Ikura and Quali Egg (4.5/5): An explosion of goodness! You will not understand what is happening in your mouth, you just know that is good... very good!

Akihabara Roll (2/5): Way too much rice. Nope!

Shinjuku Roll (3/5): Slightly better than the Akihabara Roll, but still not worth it. The crab inside is very dry, ruining the taste and juiciness of the beef. If you are getting this for the wagyu beef the nigiri version is a better choice.

Okane Handroll (3/5): A great top with a bad ending, they should really fill better the inside of the roll.

A5 Wagyu Beef Nigiri (4.5/5): What a fantastic way to eat wagyu beef. I never expected to be so enthusiastic about beef over rice!

Otoro Tuna Nigiri (5/5): Best nigiri ever!!! The Otoro is so fatty that the color of this nigiri is almost totally white, and it will melt in your mouth! Amazing!

Overall Rating (4.5/5):
Focusing only on the very good dishes, this place totally deserves the 5 stars! Outstanding Nigiris! However, I would consider Okane more a $$$ than a $$, because you don't want to order rolls if you go there ;)
author: Manuel T.

description:
We had a great time here. It's a sister restaurant to Michelin star restaurant next door. The nigiri here are the best items on the menu given that half of the items get flown from tsujiki market in Tokyo on a daily basis (on the special menu addition)

We had the scallop and sea bream nigiri - they are excellent. They ran out of the premium scallops from japan - even the other one was pretty damn good. 

Also they ran out of dessert so asked Omakase to see if they had any dessert upon our request. It was a Japanese custard with sorbet. Just fabulous and beautifully presented! Not too sweet. The custard is light and fragrant with the chilled sorbet - the combination was exquisite. So glad that they made the exception for us here. 

All the other dishes are solid but not exceptional:
Snow crab with cucumber - pretty food. Lots of crab - served a bit too chilled for my taste. 

Wagyu and tuna roll - not sure if I love the surf and turf combination here. 

Vegetable and shrimp tempura - large portion. Pretty filling. Not oily. 

Sake infused Alaskan cod - cod is difficult to do without being too fishy. For this preparation, the cod is a bit too fishy for me.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
That sake was wild. Or maybe it was simply too much sake and too little food. Either way, sake was good, food was great, service is phenomenal.

Pros:
+ Reservations called in last minute
+ Friendly service from sushi chef and servers
+ Quality fish with smoooth sake
+ Sushi bar with 4 seats

Cons:
- I woke up with a nasty headache, a scrapped knee, and some mild abrasion to the knuckles. Did I fight some girl?? Nah. I fought with that cement though. Cement wins every time.

The Good Good:
+ Otoro, $22
+ Tai (Red Snapper)
+ Kanpachi (Amberjack)
+ Kinmedai (Golden Eye Sea Bream)
+ Shima Aji (Striped Jack)

Called in last night at 7:15PM, made rezzies for 2 at the sushi bar for 8PM. On a Saturday night. That, my friends, is winning. But I guess Memorial Day weekend makes it a little easier. Chef Ken was awesome, had great conversation, took a shot together, and the rest is a blur. "Otoro please" "Again?!" Yes, chef, again. =) Also love his honesty regarding sushi spots around town and Japan.

Never leave your tricka**ho of a bestie alone at the sushi bar because she WILL holler at cute staff members. I came back from the bathroom and this damn girl hollered at Gary on my behalf. So sorry guys! I. Can't. Take. Her. Anywhere! Then again, I got smashed at the sushi bar so I guess I can't be taken anywhere either. BUT we had a good time and that's all that matters.

Grand finale was probably turning around to see that one guy that runs Omakase. What's his name again? Jackson Yu! Yea, see what happens when you drink too much. Recognized his face but that name recall part of my brain just shut down.

About that bill. I woke up to a Venmo paid amount for $150. So we spent $300 on two bottles of sake and I guess...hella nigiri? But I don't recall eating much. Which is probably why I toppled in 1.5hours.

Good sushi. Dangerous sake. Great staff. I'd come back.
author: Fanny W.

description:
Was in town for a wedding so I had limited meals to enjoy. This place did not disappoint! We went for dinner early so we were promptly seated even without reservations. The servers were friendly and asked us if we minded being in their promo shots. They respect customer privacy! 
Now for the food! As someone who recently visited japan, I was very happy with Okane. The food was amazing! 
 beef suikiyaki - met expectations. 
salmon ikura chazuke - love it! The salmon was cooked just right, placed delicately on top so the savory broth didn't overcook it when poored. It was the best chazuke I've had. Nothing was left in the bowl by the time we were done.
Harajuku roll - the lotus root gave it a nice twist!
Okane handroll - so. Good. The uni and shiso leaf was a delightful combination of flavors.

Worth the splurg!!
author: Jacky L.

description:
Met up with my daughter mid week to have a sushi dinner at Okane. I had bookmarked Okane a while back. Located in in SoMa its on the ground floor of a new large multi use building. Upon arriving the host told us it would be a 45 minute wait and they took down our cell number. Since we were waiting for one more person in our dinner party, we went around the corner to grab a couple of drinks at Saap Ver Thai. 20 minutes later right after our drinks and apps arrived Okane called and told us, our table was ready. After getting seated we perused the menu and ordered the following:

Sashimi 
Kinmedai
Hirame 
Aji (whole fish )

Nigiri 
Ocean trout 
Japanese Uni 
Scallops 
Japanese Hamachi
Ama Ebi 

Oysters
Ankimo 

Cooked items
Chawan Mushi 
Hamachi Kama 

All if the items were very good with the exception of the Ankimo which was way over cooked and very hard. See pic

Service was excellent and the pace of the meal was just right. Street parking might be tough,  but I got a space right across the street. $240
author: George F.

description:
Came here for lunch and just wanted to order the sushi set but once I saw the menu and the special nigiri they offered, I couldn't stop myself from ordering more (a lot more) and I was happy that I did.

This is the sister restaurant to Omakase next door (one of the top Japanese restaurants in SF) but they source the fish from the same place (really, really fresh fish flown in from Japan).  I ordered the sushi set, the Alaskan cod, the chicken Karaage, a couple of special pieces (Amaebi and A5 Wagyu) and the white sesame ice cream. 

As expected, all of the sushi pieces were perfect and fresh. What was unexpectedly good was the Karaage and the Alaskan cod (lots of places in SF offer a version of this dish but this is one of the better ones).  Service and ambiance were both great. Prices are about average for a casual Japanese restaurant In SF. Highly recommended for lunch or dinner.
author: Andrew S.

description:
We love this pace a lot. the food is yummy and the service is excellent. We had Charling and Irean this past Saturday and they're both really sweet and attentive. We'll be back very soon!

I was also there the week before to celebrate a friends bday. They all love this place too and had lots of fun!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
Shijuku roll (with A5 wagyu beef!), seared scallop nigiri and the oysters (with all the extras!) were my favorites. Was pretty packed for a random Thursday night, probably eating with the rest of the locals in the neighborhood.

I'd probably come back, and probably only order the oysters. Yum! Uni, quail egg, ikura (?) with oysters. Can't go wrong with that!
author: Cal C.

description:
Wrapped up my foodie weekend with this gem. Sister restaurant to the famed Omakase next door, make sure you get plenty of nigiri and sashimi vs the cooked dishes. That'll be your best experience. 

I am happy to say that everything tasted amazing. The fish isnt as 'melt in your mouth' as you'd get at Omakase or any other $$$$ sushi spot, but they know what they're doing and this is a great sushi spot without having to break the bank. 

We ordered the uni, toro tuna, scallops, seafood hotpot, hamachi kama, salad and one eel roll. They even rolled out a black sesame ice cream with mollasses sauce for the bday desserts. 

Thanks and see you again soon!
author: Mandi W.

description:
Gary, thank you so much for another great experience. We had a wonderful time last night and the dessert that came over from Omakase for my boyfriend was delicious and beautiful. I have been raving and raving about this place to everyone I know and this restaurant has cemented itself into our mental list of Japanese restaurants. I was so excited, I forgot to take pictures! Next time I won't miss it! You deserve the promotion. It was great to see you, and thank you to your staff for choosing items we ordered to serve in a perfectly choiced course style way. It really is unbelievable when you can connect to a place of business like this, and I'm glad we found you! See you next time!

Thank you,
Gauri
author: Gauri V.

description:
This a review of their take out.

The fish quality was pretty bad to the point where I didn't even care to eat it. The hamachi and salmon nigiri did not taste fresh at all. Ordered the ginza and roppongi as well. Neither were edible enough to finish. Same issue with fish quality. Every dish came off as bottom of the barrel fish.
author: J. K.

description:
A bit hard to find, but great food and service.

The space is a little cramped as many restaurants are in SF. As a result, I got to overhear the guy next to me mentoring his lady friend. 

The shinjuku roll was delectable, with the seared wagyu beef as the highlight. 

The okane handroll (not pictured) was also delicious (and crunchy), but with only one to share, I had to get over my germaphobia. 

The salmon and ikura chazuke (also not pictured) was light and soothing. 

The beef sukiyaki was a relatively large portion size, but slightly too salty. They very graciously served us another more watered down version.
author: Aerin Y.

description:
5 stars for sure!!!! We came here on a Saturday night at 7:30pm and had the time of our LIVES lemme tell ya. We ordered the daikon & cucumber salad, two okane hand rolls, the sake sashimi, and the beef sukiyaki, which was a good amount for two people. I don't even know what was the highlight because all of it was SO GOOD. 

The salad was really big (so it's def a bang for your bucc) and super light & refreshing. I feel like a lot of Japanese restaurants drench their salads with sauce until it's salty af, but not Okane. The sukiyaki came with the most perfectly cooked egg ever, like i've seen maybe 10 perfectly poached eggs in my life and this was one of them. The beef was really juicy and soft and thin. Both are perfect for sharing between two or three people, since their portions are so big. 

The restaurant has a lot seating for such a small space (without being cramped). It was pretty quiet so it's a good place for talking. The environment was fancy but also casual if that makes sense, so like it's a good date night place but also you don't need to dress up. If you wanted to you could probably get a sick insta from it too because the inside is pretty.

The service was the fastest i've ever seen for a sit down Japanese restaurant. Our reservation was at 7:30 and we paid the check at legit 8:02, and we weren't even in a rush or anything. The food came out super fast and the servers were really good at checking up on us, refilling water, clearing plates etc. 

Hope to come back again and try some other dishes!!!
author: Brittany H.

description:
I came here in October for a late dinner with one of my best friends. She had heard great things about this restaurant so we drove over for dinner. Seating wasn't an issue that evening. We had a nice table by the window. 

I don't remember the details of each dish so hopefully the pictures will make up for it. 
 
We had:

Salmon Aburi:

- really good but expensive at $19. We had two orders because it was that delicious

Lotus chips:

- meh. Nicely crunchy but nothing special

Scallop uni nigiri:

- delicious, fresh, but oh so pricey at $15

Tai chazuke:

- pretty presentation but the tea broth tasted too mild

Salmon tartare:

- don't order this. Order the salmon arburi instead.

Chicken wings:

- fried too long, tasted dry

Service was pleasant. It's a cute little restaurant. I'd return to try other items if I were back in town.
author: Faye L.

description:
My coworker was craving udon. This was the closest place to work that offered udon, so we came here for lunch today around 12:45. I always go a few stores down to the French bakery or Starbucks.  Upon walking in, I thought that the decor was very modern and sleek. 

We got seated right away. There's lots of seating inside to accommodate the lunch rush. My coworker and I both ordered the ontama sukiyaki udon which comes with thin slices of beef, a softly cooked egg, and green onions. The food came pretty quickly and I liked the presentation a lot. The broth was very flavorful! I normally do not drink the broth from ramen or udon. However, this broth was so tasty that I couldn't stop! The beef was cooked nicely and well season. I think they were going for a soft boiled egg which maybe what they mean when they said softly cooked on the menu? The egg was not soft boiled. Think fried egg shape with all the way cooked yolk. 

At $12 dollars a bowl, it's a bit on the pricey side for udon. But service was attentive and friendly. They were also able to split our bill three ways, which was incredibly nice of them. It's a bit of a walk from the office, but my coworker and I have agreed to be back!
author: Cynthia T.

description:
Usually, my friend and I satisfy our sushi craving by ordering a giant platter for four, drinking whiskey, and binging Futurama at my place. We decided to keep it classy for once and have lunch at Okane in the middle of our workday.

We were seated immediately, and there was an expected lunch crowd filling up the remainder of the restaurant. The experience was nice and service was relatively quick, but there's few things that didn't quite resonate with me at Okane.

First, we ordered three items to share: Akhihabara Roll, Roppongi Roll, and Kappabashi Roll. We devoured everything in no time and were still hungry. The rolls were pricey for the amount of food. Yes the ingredients were fresh, but there wasn't much of it. So disappointing that we ended up going somewhere else to eat more food. Blasphemous.

Also, there was no soy sauce on the table, and we had to ask for it. Kind of inconvenient but I get they want to eliminate clutter on the table. They allot a certain amount of soy sauce then walk away with the receptacle. Never seen a place do that before. 

And lastly like I said, it's pretty pricey restaurant for sushi that doesn't fill you up. It's a classy place for a nice business lunch, but expect to walk away thinking about dinner already. Would I come back here? Nope. Did I like the food? Yes. Just not my kind of sushi restaurant.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Good sushi + izakaya spot. The food comes out fast - we almost couldn't keep up with it. It's not the most spectacular Japanese I've had, but it's solid, and reasonably priced, and easy to get a reservation with a few day's notice. 

We ordered a lot and by the end of the meal I was having a hard time finishing everything, so that may have impacted my review on some things like the Tai Chazuke. 

Note Okane is right next door to Omakase, and from the outside they look like just one continuous restaurant. My friend and I each went to the wrong place by accident at first!

VEGETABLE IPPIN
* Fried Lotus Root Chips ($5) - 3.5 stars
Quite crisp, and the wasabi mayo was very heavy.

* Agedashi Tofu ($9.50) - 3.5 stars
Good, but I wish the tofu was a little more silky.

MEAT IPPIN
* Jidori Egg Chawanushi ($8) - 4 stars.
Nice! Simple. Steamed egg with tempura and some bok choy.

* Beef Sukiyaki ($16) - 4 stars
Love the vermicelli noodles and the green veggies. Great for my noodle soup craving!

RICE & NOODLES
* Tai Chazuke ($12) - 3 stars
Good simple rice & soup dish. I thought the salmon was a little overcooked, but I was also really full at this point.

CHEF'S CHOICE SASHIMI
* Hamachi Kama ($15) - 3.5 stars
This was fine - just not the sashimi I was personally in the mood for.

SPECIALTY ROLLS
* Kappabashi ($13) - 4 stars
Good! Nothing spectacular, but if you like tuna and cucumber, this is good.

* Shinjuku ($25) - 4 stars
Of course the A5 wagyu was good, but you really pay for this, and I didn't love the crab. I wouldn't get this again, but enjoyed the one-time novelty.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Probably my favorite sushi place in SF!! Their specialty rolls are to die for. I also love the Udon! Omg sooo good. Great friendly service too. Would highly recommend going there!!!
author: Asher B.

description:
I was hoping to try a less expensive version of Omakase. However, dishes were a hit or miss. Unfortunately, I wasn't impressed by the dinner, but maybe I'll come back for brunch someday. These are my thoughts on what we ordered:

Grilled cod: the best dish we ordered. The cod was buttery and well seasoned. 
Saba karaage: this tastes like pan fried mackerel that my mom makes, but with pickled vegetables on the side. Make sure to eat the fish with the veggies, which brings out the flavor of the mackerel in a different way. 
Toriteba karaage: these were amazing and the crunch was equivalent to that of chips. The sauce was also really good. 
Oysters on the half shell with uni ikura quail egg: the oysters were overwhelming and had a bitter aftertaste that couldn't be quelled by the sweetness of the uni, ikura & quail egg. I wish the oysters were smaller and sweeter. 
Shinjuku roll: this had a great texture, but the A5 beef didn't have much flavor or fattiness. The creaminess of the avocado and sweetness of the snow crab paired well though. 

In terms of service, the servers were friendly, but were not organized in terms of handling our order (we had a couple people take our order and then they got confused delivering dishes to us). I was disappointed that many of the dishes came out at once, and I was rushing to finish eating some of the food before they went cold.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Tried this place twice, and none of the food really spoke out to me. 

The lotus chips were good, and I tried a chef's choice sashimi platter today with my preference of scallops and salmon. All of it was okay, but nothing exemplary. I can't say that I would come back for more.

My friend ordered the tofu dish and veggie tempura. 

Overall, the best thing actually was the tofu last night. 

Service and decor were great, but the food just okay. I found making a choice kind of hard- maybe adding dinner sets or a course meal?
author: Corinna T.

description: What a great atmosphere and staff. Sydney took great care of us. My son who is 6 branched out and tried it all! Highly recommend Salmon Aburi, Ginza and Roppongi Rolls. The edamame with smoked soy sauce is super fun. Thank you and we'll be back!
author: Jeana F.

description: Food quality was good. Fish was fresh, nigiri pretty solid. Cooked sides were also good. Above average price for above average food. 2nd or 3rd date spot when you're willing to invest. Good spot with a group of 4 to eat well and drink before a night out.
author: Pat K.

description:
Food was good (my table had orders of sushi, sashimi, chicken skewers, shiitake mushrooms) but the service was terrible. We arrived without a reservation on a Friday night around 7:40pm (table of 4) and saw that there was seating space. The hostess asked us if we would be able to leave by 9pm and we said yes. She handed us menus and asked us to order our food by the entrance of the restaurant while they get the table ready for us. It was strange to order by the front door but we obliged. We were prompted several times by the hostess to order quickly and we ordered food to share family-style. She looked at our order and told us that we should get 3-4 more dishes and we should order now and not order after we've gotten food. We got a few more and she asked if we wanted one more. We declined, as it was a lot of food. One friend in our party commented, "That was intense." 

We sat down, the food arrived quickly, it was all yummy, but when the time rolled around to 8:42pm, and we were finished with our food and got the check. The hostess came by our table and very rudely asked us if we are ready to go. We hadn't paid the check yet, clearly, and it was 18 minutes before her deadline of 9pm. We said no we just need to pay the check. She came around a few minutes later to do a perfunctory wipe of our table, reminding us that we needed to leave by 9pm. Okay we get it. We sat for a few more minutes. She stopped by our table again. Yes we are aware that we have to leave soon. The whole experience with the hostess was anxiety-producing and uncomfortable and really colored the experience in a highly negative way. Not worth it.
author: Jessica Z.

description: I stopped in for a quick lunch and was pleased with the excellent service and delicious food. Today was my first time here as I recently moved to the Bay Area, and I feel like I've already found one of my favorite spots.
author: Deema A.

description: Their Ginza roll is absolutely PERFECT. Akihabara and Shibuya were also great. Ambiance is on the quieter/more intimate side, good for actually being able to hear your conversations. Only downside was that the portions are a bit small for the price
author: Maggie S.

description: This place is gorgous！ We tried the oyster and it's super fresh with a hint of sweet，tastes like heaven！Salmon sashimi was good too，toro was yummy. Will defenitly come again！
author: He H.

description:
Came here for lunch on a weekend with a friend. Restaurant wasn't too packed since we went after the lunch hour. I would recommend making a reservation since they take them and the seating is small.

[Lunch]
The 3/5 rating is primarily for the dish my server recommended me. I had the Sukiyaki while my friend had the ontama udon. The sukiyaki was really sweet and had way too many glass noodles to meat/vegetable ratio. The sweetness was very overpowering. I did really enjoy my friend's Ontama udon - the ratio was great here and there was plenty of meat. We also ordered the fried young chicken - it was amazing! Highly recommend as the chicken was the juiciest I've had in a while. We also ordered some nigiri - uni, toro, and salmon. I didn't find anything super amazing about the fish; it was something I felt like I could find at your better than average moderately priced sushi joint. 

[Service]
Servers were very friendly and attentive. They did forget our fried chicken dish but immediately brought it out once we asked. 

Overall, I would definitely come back and get the ontama udon, the highlight of the restaurant. Given its sister restaurant is the famous Omakase, I was a bit let down by the nigiri I had here, hence the 3/5 rating. Hopefully my next meal here will improve my rating!
author: Alice Z.

description:
Very POOR service. We were so excited to try this place, made a reservation, got there on time, when seated, It took almost 15 minutes until our waitress came to our table to take our order. We quickly ordered a few appetizers and hot sake. She came back after 20 minutes with our appetizers and we ordered our main dishes and some more appetizers. 

After over 30 mins, she came back with only two of our orders. We waited a bit to get our two other orders, so we can all eat together, but it took so long and after over 45 minutes that nobody came to our table, we gave up. She never even came back to fill up our water. We had to keep asking someone to bring some water to the table. 

It was very disappointing to have to go through that. We were not able to enjoy our time together and have a nice and relaxing dinner.
author: Reza N.

description: I really love their Shinjuku roll and Okane hand roll, and their presentation of food. I'll be back the next time when I crave for authentic Japanese food.
author: Yuxi C.

description:
A tad overpriced for the portions, taste and service you receive. I ordered:
YoDu tofu - minimal flavor until you add the soy sauce which comes on the side. 
Cucumber and Diakon salad- I tasted little cucumber; not your traditional Asian cucumber salad. 
Rice w softly cooked egg - this was actually pretty good. Just very small portion. Once you mix the egg and spices, the flavored blend well together. 
Shrimp & veggie tempura - $16 for a few pieces! 
Also the sake is served cold, which to me is odd. 

Note- not vegetarian friendly.
author: Rob M.

description:
I booked a reservation here for my monthly coworker dinner. It was a Thursday night and it was pretty empty so we got seated immediately. Overall nothing about this place stood out to me. The sake I ordered from their menu happened to be sold out. The service was average as well: First nobody had chopsticks when the food came out, then my friend ordered a drink that never came so we had to follow up on that, and lastly at the end of the dinner they quickly cleared our table and my friend's drink that was still half full. They didn't even ask her if she was done with it (which she was not) so they had to bring the unfinished drink back from the kitchen. 

We essentially finished all the food we ordered within 45mins because the food came out all at once. It didn't create an environment where we could hang out and chat; it actually felt rushed. We each paid about $50 and were still starving. Instead of ordering more we made a group decision to go to another place to finish off the night with some tater tots :)

To be fair, the food was good but not stand out from other sushi/japanese restaurants in the city. It's really not worth the price. I'd recommend using your money elsewhere and skipping this place. 

Random fact this place is part of the restaurant chain owned by Omakase Restaurant Group (ORG) that also owns the Omakase restaurant next door and dumpling time that's right around the corner.
author: Kathy L.

description: Their was an Asian waitresses  who served us. She was very unpleasant to our group from the moment we first walk in. Though the food came out quick but the food wasn't good and the portion of the noodle soup was definitely smaller .
author: Aniko N.

description:
Real talk. The entrance to this spot is hella confusing. My friend and I walked in for our 6:30pm reservation...thinking it was Okane...only to realize it was Omakase. Here we were in our ripped jeans, plus me in my "vaca vibes" crop top, thinking holy shit we are SUPER underdressed?! And wait wtf, we booked a Michelin star restaurant for dinner?! Hostess checked us real quick and said Okane is next door. Whoops. So tl;dr two sushi restaurants next door to one another. Omakase to the left; Okane to the right. 

OKAY, soo when we got to the correct restaurant I was thinking, well damn, Omakase must hate being next door to this "shittier" restaurant w the wrong ppl coming in all the time. And again, I got fact checked by my friend who went to the restroom and saw a newspaper article on the wall, detailing Okane being the sister restaurant to Omakase. Well guys, we were in for a better than expected Saturday night sushi experience! 

I got a lot more excited about dinner and HAD to get the Hokkaido uni nigiri at that point. My friend's not much of a sashimi/nigiri eater, so we got two of the rolls (one was basically a 49er roll w a diff name and the other was a shrimp tempura w hamachi on top situation). For apps, we started w the lotus root chips and agedashi tofu. Anddd to finish we got the udon with soft boiled egg. YUM. 

Honestly, I was really happy with the sashimi quality (no surprise if they're right next door to omakase)...I meannn, they've got to be getting the fish frm the same vendors (maybe just slightly lower quality and I'm okay w that on a regular sushi night). Also, the udon had great bite to it, and the soft boiled egg was blanched to perfection. I'm not a huge fan of rolls either, but I'd say it was pretty good quality. 

Definitely a come backer. Prices are higher than a nightly sushi dinner spot, but nothing compared to what you'd pay for Omakase next door. About 45pp. Service was also pretty good. Keeping them at 4 stars bc there wasn't anything EXTRAordinary about the dinner, but still good enough for me to patron again.
author: Jennifer L.

description: This place is one of the most popular restaurant in SOMA. Service is up to standard and has good selection of Japanese sakes. Food is fresh but however they put too much sauce in almost every dish. I ordered beef and chicken skewers, black cod, honestly they don't taste much different due to the overloaded sauce.  I think a usual fan of Japanese food would appreciate the natural taste of freshness of the material more. I would give 3.5 star as the food is not up to 4 but better compare to other 3s in the city.
author: Helena H.

description: My sister and I can agree that the oysters were our favorite dish from our most recent trip to San Francisco. We saw a picture on Yelp, read a couple of reviews, and knew that we needed to try it for ourselves. It was life changing - not to be dramatic. Who knew these oysters could pack so much punch in one slurp?! If I go back to San Francisco, I am definitely coming back for some more.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Good service, good quality fish, pretty good lotus chips, good sushi in general, but not "omakase" level. I recommend the Otoro tuna belly and the sake salmon belly. 

I have to say though, while it is good quality fish I still feel the quality or quantity does NOT justify the excessively high prices... the same dish in many other major cities in the US is almost half the price of SFO. Pretentious yes, or maybe taxed to hell to drive up the price, but still good. Just be prepared to pay the inflated prices. 4-stars, would have been 5 if the value was there... but it isn't. Expect a $100-$120ish tab for two.
author: Chris K.

description: Love love love. Shibuya and Kapabashi rolls are my favorite. Any of the "dons" are yummy and so is the Sukiyaki. The best part is that they're available for delivery through Caviar!!!
author: Danielle Y.

description:
I'd give this place a 4.5 if they allowed that on Yelp. We got a relatively last minute reservation for this past Saturday for dinner. We were a bit surprised it wasn't more busy for a Saturday but it's in an area a little more out of the way for most people.

The experience was really good all the way around. My fiancée is currently not eating soy or gluten and they were extremely accommodating. They allowed us to order sets of 2 nigiri with one fully dressed and the other without the soy/gluten. The chef made a nice little tray of lemons, yuzu vinegar, truffle oil, and salt to help flavor the various fish and instructions were given to the server for which things to put on each fish as we received them.

All of the fish we were served was very fresh and delicious, while there were a few that really stood out like the amberjack, grunt and the fresh hokkaido scallop. They also custom made us a cucumber avocado roll which we didn't see on the menu. We only did sushi this time around but we hope to come back to try some of the izakaya type dishes as well.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Not impressed at all. This place would fail in Tokyo - where we live - within a month. Hard, dry rice in the oyakodon, weird breading on the tempura shrimp in the udon. Very poor presentation for the oshinko. 2stars only because they have good beer. Friendly service, but slow preparation. 

Don't waste your money here. Many better places to eat.
author: Joe P.

description:
Love love finding new sushi places to eat in sf. This place definitely did not disappoint. 

We had reservations here on new year. The restaurant is a lot bigger than it appears outside. I love the face mask that lined the back wall as decorations. Really nice touch. My friends and I decided to order several things and share. Started off with otama udon, the roppongi , shinjuku, ginza roll, an order of local uni for me, and a bottle of sake. Everything was so good! I definitely enjoyed all the rolls and were able to taste how fresh the fish were. And don't get me started on the uni, I love that they serve it without nori wrapped around the rice here. The uni literally just melted like butter, it was so good I had to order another one haha. The wait for the roppongi roll took a lot longer than anything else and we didn't mind. We honestly just thought because of new year everything was probably backed up but the staff had noticed and bought out lotus chips and another ginza roll for us while we waited. It was really unexpected and we all comment at how amazing their service was. I understand getting one thing but two? The service alone will be the reason I'll keep wanting to come back here :). It was really a nice treat for us and they most definitely didn't have to do that for us. 

Ill just continue my hunt for awesome uni in Seattle while I day dream of the next time I'll be able to have the delicious food from Okane again.
author: Linh N.

description: Recommended by an acquaintance... Some unusual sushi I've not seen anywhere else.  Really enjoyed it.  Very busy.  Loved that they use actual crab rather than fake crab. Not a huge menu but that probation how they keep everything fresh.
author: William L.

description: Glad I went to this place instead of waiting for a long line of Ramen place.  I'll go back next time when I am in town.
author: masa t.

description:
Japanese Brunch? Have you ever heard of such a thing in the city? Once my girls told me they had Japanese brunch here, I was committed to making this happen! Easy to make a reservation the three times I have been here: twice for brunch, once for dinner. Open table! 
I just found out they have indefinitely discontinued doing brunch ):
I recently went back for a casual Japanese comfort meal on a Friday and Okane did not disappoint! My friends asked me what's Japanese comfort meal? No stress, just order whatever you want (it's reasonably priced) and decently made. 

For two people, we had:
Hamachi Kama (Yellow Tail Collar) - another must every time I see it, good, not dry!
Sukiyaki - lots of vegetables, huge portion, on the sweeter side 
Loaded Oysters (with the Uni, Ikura and Quail Egg) - they give you 6 so yummy!
Chawanmushi (this is the definition of Japanese comfort food) - bland but I always order this every time I see it
Hokkaido Uni nigiri ($15 for two pieces) - fresh, what can go wrong?

Everything was up to par except for the Chawanmushi, which unfortunately I would have to say, no place has quite compared to Rintaro. Bill came out to be about $100 and we were so full we barely finished.
Overall, I would have to say, the food was great, service was great (I've had friendlier service for lunch before though). Probably not a regular but will come back from time to time.
author: Miffy Y.

description:
Definitely a more upscale Japanese place,  but less expensive version of its sister restaurant next door, Omakase.

Do get the lotus chips. These are yummy and addicting.
Hamachi is good too.
Any fatty tuna is my favorite. And this place gets it right.
One of the rolls I normally get is pretty good too, but I forgot the name. Not the one with the beef in it...
Good sake selection, and wine list.
Elegant dining area for date night, but I tend to sit at the sushi bar.

Pricing is a bit up there, but hey, this is SF, so I'm used to it by now. But I'm always down for a good sushi spot, especially in a city that has too many to choose from!
author: Nika K.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. Servers were nice and ambience was modern and clean. Food was just not up to par with everything else. 

Our server recommended us the rare special - live uni (around 5 pieces for $39). I wouldn't call my friends nor myself uni connoisseurs, but we're definitely uni lovers who have had enough to say that this was the most interesting uni we've had.. It was watery tasting with hints of bitterness. Texture was stringy and slightly crunchy. We were quite confused to say the least, but perhaps it was just a different type of uni than we're used to.

I also ordered the salmon and ikura chazuke, which was rather disappointing as it was very bland and unimpressive. We were also charged $4 for a small cup of hot tea, which seemed a bit much. 

They do have quite an unique selection of items on their menu so I'd still come back and try out something else and hopefully have a better experience!
author: Mandy H.

description:
Came here for lunch but was too early and they only had the brunch menu. Was pretty bummed at first but turns out I was mistaken. There's not too many options for brunch but their most popular items are the set menu. The restaurant feels very intimate since its not very big, so you might also want to make reservations if you don't want to wait.

My friend and I ended up getting the set menu from the Okane Brunch Menu which also comes with a bowl of rice, miso soup and a side salad. I'm giving this place a 10/10 in terms of presentation and their creativity. This was my first time having japanese brunch so I was really excited about it. The portions looked really small and I thought I would still be hungry after this meal but man was I wrong. 

Megumi: 
- Stewed beef: in layman's term its basically your beef yakiniku. Nothing really special.
- Miso gindara: Gindara was marinated well and was really soft. Did not taste fishy at all. 
- Onsen tamago with truffle oil: This to me was the highlight of the meal. You have a perfectly poached egg in a bowl with a white creamy sauce, asparagus and a hint of truffle oil. No words can describe how good this dish is. They suggest you to pour it over your bowl of rice but I personally like my rice plain. 
- Sushi sphere: Your typical nigiri (salmon, toro and white tuna)
- Potato salad: Nothing special
- Crispy baby anchovies: Don't remember getting this with my meal but we did get a bunch of pickled vegetables 

Miyabi: 
- Stewed pork belly: Melts in your mouth! Similar to caramelized pork belly in chinese restaurants. 
- Braised chicken and turnip (soup): Clear broth with chicken and daikon, A little bitter, maybe they didn't wash the daikon properly or cooked it too long
- Smoked salmon: Tasted like the miso gindara but with an additional smokiness to it. The fish itself is smooth and doesn't smell fishy.
- Tamago: Pretty good tamago, perfect sweetness level
- Sesame tofu: Tofu had a weird texture. It was crumbly and not as smooth as your regular tofu.
- Crispy baby anchovies: Don't remember getting this with my meal but we did get a bunch of pickled vegetables 


Found out that this was actually a sister restaurant to omakase (right beside it). I would definitely come back here for their brunch experience and also to try out their dinner menu.
author: Valerie H.

description:
Food is exceptional with classy aura of Japanese interior decor. Okane's sushi chef prepared the Kuromaguro (blue fin tuna) and Mushiebi (tiger prawn), which was simply amazing. Wakadori Karaage and the Hamachi Kama are dishes I recommend as well. Price is fair for authentic Japanese cuisine.

The service was cordial and attentive, which is always a huge plus when you're dining in (the gentleman, Adrian, was phenomenal, explaining each and every dish with detail and professionalism). 

Okane is definitely a must-stop place when I'm back in the bay area.
author: Andy K.

description: Solid 4 Star I had to knock off one star for service, granted the place was packed but a hour lunch with only one drink and and order of 2 items seems a bit long...if you have a long lunch break definitely check them out, the sashimi is fresh and the plating is like omakase his other restaurant next door
author: jonathan h.

description: Love this spot. Their udon is amazing. We come here pretty frequently because the food is so good. Definitely recommended!
author: Yong-Soo C.

description:
TL;DR: delicious and gorgeous Japanese sets that come at a premium price

When I heard Okane now offered brunch, my interest was piqued and I gathered a group of friends to come and check it out. 

To be safe, we made reservations a couple days in advance, which was super easy through OpenTable. It was wide open when I made the reservation.

They call it brunch, but it's more like a Japanese breakfast set in my opinion. I ordered the Miyabi set ($22), which comes with pork belly, braised chicken, smoked salmon, tamago, and tofu. I loved the presentation, as everything comes in colorful small plates served as part of a round wooden tray (see my pictures, that will make more sense). Halfway through eating, I realized I probably wouldn't be full from the set and ordered an okonomiyaki on the side ($14). 

Food-wise, everything in the set was delicious except for the braised chicken which came in a broth, as the chicken was kind of dry and hard to chew even though it was cooked in the broth. My favorite item out of the set was probably the pork belly, as it was well flavored and melted in my mouth. Something to keep in mind is that the sets are all on the small side, so if you're hungry you might want to order some of the appetizers to share.

I was disappointed by my okonomiyaki, though. I don't know if it's because they were rushing to get it out to me because I ordered it halfway through my meal, but it came out maybe 80% cooked and there was still some of the uncooked mix that pooled at the bottom of the dish. They must have heard my friends and I talking about it (or maybe they noticed themselves), because they comped it for us. That's what I call good service! 

One thing that threw us off was the prices on the menu were a little bit higher than the prices we saw on their website. The Miyabi set is actually $22 and the Megumi set is $25. We had already scoped out what we wanted before coming, but the increased prices made us rethink our choices.

I'm glad I came to try it out once, but it's honestly a bit too pricy for what it is and the portions that you get, so I don't think I will be back for brunch/lunch.

Parking in the area is street parking. The restaurant is on a street with all metered spots, but I parked a block away in an apartment parking lot and that was free. Score!
author: Dianna H.

description: Came here for lunch and dinner. 5 stars for the food and service. The menu changes slightly so make sure to try everything if you can! Affordable and fun with great service.
author: Kelly T.

description: Came here cause we didn't want to wait at dumpling house, didn't know they were sister restaurants along with omakase! Really good dining experience here. Great food, and even better service (Gary is awesome!). We got the uni nigiri (hokkaido is more expensive, but so sweet and not overly sea-tasting), the beef sukiyaki (really good on a cold day- lots of fun stuff inside), and the harajuku roll (really like the lotus chips on top- a little spicy- but not too much). Great ambiance. Will be back!
author: Vivian D.

description:
I was excited about a new seemingly intimate izakaya opening up in the neighborhood close by. Reading their menu, they have got everything I liked to order when I was in homey izakaya restaurants in New York. Udon, tonkatsu, sukiyaki... it's a rarity in SF indeed. SF is all about turning everything into Californian refined instagram-friendly style, when no one has any glue what a good taste could be.

It was a very shitty day. I just wanted something warm and cozy. So I came here the first time, hoping to feel better after I left. But I only left feel warm because my udon dish was way too hot, but not cozy or satisfied. The whole meal was a bit tasteless.

I regret not getting beef sukiyaki. So I will give you one more chance for that.
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
After dining at this place 10+ times in past three months. This place is officially my favorite spot for my Japanese food.  

Their sushi chef Ken San is very good and he is definitely one of the best sushi chefs in the city 
Me and my friends always order tons of Nigiris. And if they are not busy we will ask for Omakase!

Their cooked foods are very good too. 

My favorite items from the kitchen are
- lotus chips.  OMG! That wasabi mayo goes so well with thinly sliced deep fried lotus chips 
- karaage big pieces of juicy deep fried chicken. I cannot stop craving it!
- beef sukiyaki. I am not a sukiyaki person but this place has really good sukiyaki 

Don't forget to order some sake or beer to go along with your meal. We always leave happy after the good food and delicious sake. 


Hands down one of the best places in the city to eat/ drink and hangout with friends.
author: missy C.

description: First time here and I loved it. Please come here. I'm sad this place has such little reviews because it's so freaking good and the quality of food and presentation is just A1. My boyfriend and I ordered the sukiyaki udon and harajuku roll. The harajuku roll came out first and the tuna was fresh and tender with a nice touch of a crispy lotus chip on top to balance the roll, 5/5. The sukiyaki udon was light and felt like something my mom would make at home. It hits the spot if you're eating this in cold weather. The only problem I have with the sukiyaki udon is that it didn't really taste like sukiyaki. I'm used to a sweeter and more flavorful sukiyaki, but this was more of a clear broth that wasn't as heavy. Don't get me wrong though, because I still loved it. 4.5/5 just because the name threw me off. 10/10 would recommend coming here and I'm definitely coming back soon.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Very classy Japanese food. You can watch the chefs and their super detailed knife work. 
Me and my friends came a bit too early so we were the only ones there for a little while. The servers were really nice. Helped recommend a lot of great dishes. We ordered two rolls, a cod, and a meat noodles dish. All which were really good and fresh, but not enough to satisfy us so we had to order a second round. 
I really love the decor as well. Nice ambiance. 
It was also my friend's birthday and we never said anything directly (we spoke of it in or conversations though) to the waiters until the end of our meal and they were already preparing something for her! It was an almondy ice cream with some Michu and it was not overly sweet, so it was perfect! Thank you for that :)
All in all, the food was good, but I wish it was cheaper considering the portions.
author: Vence M.

description:
Came here for brunch last weekend and I've already made another reservation for brunch again next Sunday! I think this is my new favorite place for brunch, especially because it's unique AND tasty. For those of you who have traveled to Japan, you know how delicious their breakfast is... and not to mention how their presentation is so pretty! 

They offer 4 different set meals and each one is so fulfilling and also worth every penny. They vary from pork belly, misoyaki fish, steamed egg, asparagus with eggs, and a side of miso soup and salad. I love variety in my food and it's nice you get ~5 different small dishes. We also shared an okonomiyaki -- soo gooood! It has more cabbage:pancake ratio, btw. You have to try this place! Especially for brunch! Can't wait to come back and would love to try their dinner.
author: Janet H.

description: Much better than Rintaro.  The food here actually tastes like real Japanese food.  Not cheap.  Definitely special occasion only.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Came for Japanese breakfast on the weekend or what they called "brunch" presumably to set expectation that they don't serve this every day and not until 10am.

They upsold us to get an a la carte order on top of the set breakfast saying they think it's necessary (though if it's true why even have a set menu that won't fill you?). Turns out it was too much food with 2 sets and a lobster rice a la carte for 2 people.

Lobster gohan rice (3.5/5) - it was flavorful but rather mushy. Could have benefited from having some of the rice be crispy. Nice contrasting bitter vegetables included

Miyabi set (4/5) - pretty filling for a morning meal. The tofu is similar to what you'd find in Kyoto for fresh tofu so I was impressed. The smoked salmon is also prepared very traditionally and not your typical western fish preparation. I did wish the fried anchovies were saltier. The plating is beautiful and the starter salad and miso soup were well prepared. The Japanese pickles were legit too

Nagomi (4/5) - even though its vegetarian it's filling cause the deep fried yam is a huge portion. Pretty tasty for vegetarian 

I'd come back for Japanese breakfast since it was a pretty legit execution and really only game in town as far as I know.
author: Victor W.

description:
I was here twice, and because I forgot to review this place, I accidentally came back. I was looking for a place to eat sushi for lunch with my sushi loving friend and Okane was still in my bookmarks so we ate here today. 
To be honest, I was expecting a less expensive version of Omakase, but I left underwhelmed and did not like it that much. It was just OK for me but I wouldn't take an Uber here next time.
author: Anelya S.

description:
Made a reservation for two people for lunch.

I got the sushi lunch set (comes with nigiri, roll, tamago and miso soup) as well as tempura vegetables. My friend got the mushroom appetizer and the shimofuri tuna.

Everything was beautifully platted!
The tempura vegetables were tasty although the sauce was a little bit too salty.
For the nigiri, some fish were really tender and soft but others felt dry. The roll was simply tuna, too plain for me.
My friend loved her dishes and it was enough food for us.

Service was fast and nice!
author: Coralie S.

description:
What a cute little restaurant right down the street from my brother's place! The family and I decided to go for a early lunch on a weekday (we were a little sad they only had their brunch option on the weekend) and we were the first ones there. It is a small place with a prominently displayed sushi bar. I loved the brightly colored artwork and the patterned light shades- sometimes the small details make a place just pop.

The servers were polite and brought water right away. The only thing I would ding them for was not bringing all of our food out at the same time. There was a few minutes of lag time between each entree. But the food was really beautifully plated and tasty! We ordered two of the sushi lunch sets, the salmon teriyaki bento, and a udon bowl. 

The bento box was so pretty! Two pieces of teriyaki glazed salmon nestled next to a mound of salad that was topped by crunchy tiny unidentifiable white balls. A small serving of rice was dusted with some seaweed in it's own compartment. In the last compartment was a small pile of pickles. It also came with miso soup, which arrived earlier than the main bento box. 

The nabeyaki udon is the one with shrimp tempura, chicken, wakame, green onion, and fish cake. It arrives in a very hot, covered pot that the server lifts up with a flourish and a warning about the hot pot. The only downside to the covered pot is that the tempura is soggy before it even arrives. However, the bowl was good and filling, with lots of chicken. 

The sushi lunch set is comprised of 5 nigiri, 1 roll, 1 tamago, and miso soup. The sushi is chef's choice but they can work with you to customize it to your liking as well. The sushi rice seems already seasoned with soy sauce- it is a mixed brown and white color. It made the tuna(?) roll look a little muddled. The nigiri were fresh with generous slices of fish- we had salmon, tuna, and a few others that I couldn't identify on sight.

A great place for a sushi lunch. It seemed other people agreed beacuse they were trickling in around lunchtime and the place was half-full when we left. They also had several carryout orders. I bet the weekend brunch is wonderful as well!
author: Sally C.

description:
Food was great, but portions were small and pricy. Would recommend their sushi rolls, cod, grilled mushrooms and of course, uni! We ordered:

-Chef's sashimi: 8 pieces of fresh fish - nothing extra special here.
-Daikon salad: small bunch of mixed greens with a couple pickled cucumbers and daikon. Tasted okay...not worth the price.
-4 pieces of UNI NIGIRI: your typical hokkaido uni, which was melt in your mouth good and super creamy! 
-Agedashi tofu: came with 4 pieces of tofu and a couple fried vegetables. Breading on the tofu was not too thick nor too thin
-COD: buttery and super good, but two small pieces of fish. despite the small portions, I still highly recommend!
-rolls: well made and really delicious! 
-beef skewers: recommend the chicken ones actually. the beef was a bit hard to chew and not very tender
-chicken skewers: juicy with a really great sauce!
-grilled mushrooms: surprisingly really delicious! the yuzu gave the mushrooms just the perfect amount of tanginess. one of my favs of the night!

Not sure if I'd come back again given the portions and the price. I'll keep trying other japanese restaurants in sf and will see how they fare with okane (portion size vs. price)
author: Cynthia H.

description: I ordered omakase, which was the chef selected meal and paid around $80 per person. We only got some sushi (of which the wagyu beef sushi was the best.... although I was at a sushi place...), started off with some fish liver, got like 4 pieces of sashimi, and some sesame ice cream at the end.... Compared to the price I paid, I do not think that I got a good quality meal nor got a decent portion of food. We had to order beef sukiyaki at the end of the 2 hour meal to fill up our tummy...  If you want to have an enjoyable meal, I would recommend ordering dishes from the menu instead of choosing omakase. The atmosphere was nice though.
author: Jane L.

description:
We came here with a group of 8 to celebrate a birthday. I made a reservation online for 5, but they were able to accommodate our large group luckily. It's a pretty small restaurant so I would recommend you to not risk this like I did if you plan on coming with a lot of people. Given we were seated at their largest table, they really could not go beyond 8 without splitting tables. 

The menu was interestingly displayed. It's not the easiest menu to read and we weren't sure how to gauge the portion sizes. I think this restaurant is mostly known for their sushi since they're sister restaurants to omakase. 

The rolls are all decently good. Fish is pretty fresh. I ordered the chicken skewers, and would definitely not recommend you order them. It's $13+ for 2 skewers of chicken + 1 skewer of some chicken ball. I thought the chicken was quite dry and not worth it for the high price tag.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Surprisingly, I prefer Okane over Omakase next door. We sat at the bar in front of the chef, who was super busy, but still managed to talk to us about the dishes he was making.  We ordered the shimofuri hamachi, shinjuku roll, and the chef's choice sashimi. The fish was SO fresh and smooth and buttery. Even though there are only 8 pieces in the chef's choice sashimi, they were 8 fat pieces. The shinjuku roll was a great combination between crab and wagyu-- something I've never tried before. 

Even though the food was excellent, the service was kind of lacking. I asked for water three times and never had my glass refilled. Our waitress basically took our order and spent the rest of the meal chatting to other staff and didn't come back till she brought out check. 

This place gets super busy so try to get reservations beforehand and specifically request seats at the bar.
author: Chanel C.

description:
They greet you at the door and the sushi bar is right near the entrance.  Sizable restaurant with a bit of quaintness. 

Sukiyaki is to be ordered if the weather outside is cold! They have uni from Hokkaido and local. I got the local for the freshness. Toro belly nigiri was yummy!  Chawan Mushi was a nice, warm intake to the palate.  Roppongi is a healthy option with no rice wrapped around the roll and sashimi in between. Cucumber is the wrap and they display it very prettily. 

Sake was pleasant and heated the body up from the chilly weather. 

Solid selections of tidbits on izakaya dishes, sashimi, sushi rolls, noodle soups and skewers.
author: Tiffany D.

description: This spot was legit. Everything was really fresh and just tasted like the ocean. Not gonna lie the prices are pretty high here but the quality is there. I had the uni here and I was super blown away tasted just like Japan. I also had some really good cold sake here that is smooth as well, along with their Japanese Lager. I can't wait to come back to the bay and dine here again.
author: Danny L.

description: Decided to try this place spontaneously since it's near our office. The sake selection was great. However, seemed like everything here was served in these clay pots. The tofu dish and the beef sukiyaki were too similar. I was really looking forward to the beef sukiyaki but it was way over cooked. The beef was chewy. The Steamed Oysters and Asari clams were very delicious, I drank some of the broth too. I'll probably come back for more special occasion type but this would not replace our weekly go to places.
author: Anyta L.

description: Delicious sushi. 6 oysters with topping (uni, I Kira Quill egg) is so good. We also had 2 signatures both were good.
author: Natalee R.

description: Just left this restaurant because 3 waitress walked past me as I waited to be seated for ten minutes.  I was finally able to get ones attention asked if I could sit at the bar she said wait a minute and about another 5 minutes later I just left.  Not sure if my skin color was a factor or what but have never been ignored to the point that it made me feel uncomfortable and  unwanted.  I have heard great things about this place.  Next time if there is a next time I will make sure to come with my white friends.
author: Natalie K.

description:
Food was pretty good! The sesame-mayo sauce for the spinach appetizer was creamy and sweet. The karage wings were zesty and peppery. The salmon tartare and the ginza roll were both easy to eat and clean-tasting. 

All of this food shared between me and my friend was around $55 not including tip.

One downside: the waiter forgot our salmon skin handroll, but I understand since the restaurant was packed and looked understaffed. I'm thankful my friend was able to reserve this place via OpenTable.
author: Jenn H.

description:
I am pretty disappointed on the Oyako Don and Beef Sukiyaki. The egg is overcooked while the beef is undercook. The beef is sticked together that I'm pretty sure it is cookedb while frozen.
Just don't expect too much.
author: Jianhao L.

description:
Been here twice for dinner, and gotta say it's a solid Japanese spot. Sushi was fresh and good balance of the fish to rice. They had some nice variety in the specialty roles too Shibuya and Kapabashi (great for group sharing). I did try the popular lotus chips, solid choice as one of the starters. The Otama udon was allright, but usually there are specific restaurants in SF known for a good Udon bowl, notably focusing on the broth.

Drinks, only had the japanese beer on tap, I think they had one that was a specialty japanese craft beer that my friends tried and said was super tasty. Seating has always been ample here, but there are those friday/satruday nights that can get packed. They do take opentable resys too. I'm a fan of this place!
author: Howard J.

description:
I'm really really quite disappointed.... I rarely give less than 3 star review unless it's a horrible experience. 

My cousin and her boyfriend from Switzerland were in town to visit me. I wanted to impress them with amazing Japanese cuisine! But Okane really ruined their experience :( 

1) We walked in hungry and the server didn't try to even look at me and greet. I felt very unwelcoming.... 

2) We ordered food. Sushi rolls and two bento boxes. The rolls were small and expensive, except I love the A5 Wagyu roll.. hmm! 

3) The rolls came already. We were still waiting for my cousin's chicken teriyaki bento box... after 20 minutes.. still not ready and we already finished our 3 sushi rolls we ordered.. Wtheck?

4) About 30 minutes total, the server gave him the bento box with CHICKEN KARAAGE. Are you serious?? 

5) Another 5-10 minutes, they finally gave him the correct order...... late. 

6) They charge for tea at $4 each. Thanks SF 

Not sure if I'll come back here again... I spent over $120 and was hoping they would waive one of the bento boxes but they didn't.
author: Jan P.

description:
Okane is definitely my favorite Japanese place to go for good sake and delicious sushi! I usually take my friends from Japan to this place when they visit me. Servers and sushi chefs are very friendly so you should ask them for recommendations and stuff! 
My favorites are
-Wagyu nigiri
-live uni
-grilled Alaskan cod
-Ankimo 
-Hokkaido uni nigiri
-Ginza roll 
Definitely worth trying!!
author: Chika O.

description: One of the better sushi places in SF! You walk into a pretty small restaurant so the atmosphere is probably better suited for date night or catching up with an old  friend. The itamaes stand at the bar and create masterpieces, I highly recommend paying attention to them when you go as they put a lot of work into what they do. As for the food, the nigiri and sashimi are so fresh!! The restaurant shares the same fish as their sister restaurant omakase (very high end and right next door) so you're kind of getting the best of both worlds. The seasame ice is also really good, very different though. All in all, you won't find your typical American sushi rolls here but you will find much more authentic and fresh cuisine. 100% recommend!
author: Kendra W.

description:
This review is for brunch, and reflects the menu offered on the weekends, rather than the sushi offerings which I have heard are awesome. Okane offers four set brunch meals, one of which is vegetarian.  What I did not understand was why we could not mix and match the small items that comprise of a particular meal, but rather certain items were only served with certain others, and there was no way to try an individual small item without ordering a particular set meal.  I enjoyed the Miyabi meal I tried but there were other dishes in other set meals I might have liked better than some of the dishes I had. This may be my relative cultural ignorance about Japanese breakfast food, but I couldn't help voice this American impulse to simply get exactly what I want. 

Can't wait to try the sushi, once I find the right company!
author: Archana P.

description:
This place is great! Amazing food, great ambiance, and even better sake. I would def. recommend coming here as we were tired of the same old sushi spots in our area. 

Thank you for making me a happy Jew!
author: David F.

description:
The fish was good quality but I cant help but think it's extremely over priced. 
The service is also slow.  I sat there waiting a good 10-15 minutes before having to get up myself and hand them the bill.  I understand chatting up customers is nice but please make sure you don't waste other patrons time.
author: Jane T.

description: It's a neighborhood restaurant style, not many fancy things going on, but from the recipe to the quality, it is at the high level.
author: Faye L.

description:
This place is the best! The food was ridiculously good. The oysters were bomb!!! and you must add the egg and uni!! The oyster was fresh and the egg and uni added a slight sweet flavor to the freshness.. IT WAS SO GOOOOD! I will definitely come back and recommend this place to my friends. 

Quick tip: it is best to make a reservation beforehand. We went without one and sat at the communal table, which was not a problem because the food was soo gooood!!
author: Ada S.

description:
Came here on a Friday night.  It's a small place, with not that many tables so it's a good idea to make reservations.  We thankfully were able to get reservations that afternoon.

The cooked food was good.  My favorites were the 
* Chicken Mixed Skewers (the green onions on the chicken thigh were divine!) and the salad it comes with is super refreshing.  Hubby doesn't usually love greens, but he loved this one -- nice and refreshing with yuzu and slight sweetness (not too sweet).  
* Shizo Salmon onigiri (riceball) -- the rice is toasted on the outside so it's crunchy and has a great toasty smell!  so delicious!

We also enjoyed:
* Chicken Karaage -- juicy and flavorful
* Egg udon -- the broth is really nice!
* Sake Cod -- really amazing when had with the pickles & greens served, but portion is small

I found the sushi to be meh.  Pretty middle of the road.  We'll definitely be back for the cooked food!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Oh Okane, 

Thank you very much!!! ^_^
どうもありがとうございました

My authentic Izakaya experience was phenomenal.

Reservations were a breeze. I was treated as if royalty stepped foot into a grandiose royal palace. Exquisitely Superb! I would like to express my many thanks to the awesome, humble Japanese American Chef...who prefers to remain unnamed. :-P ... Perhaps, one day he'll accept written recognition!! I was very impressed by the skillful craft of each item along with beautifully precise presentation! 

Staff was on point too to my every request! Adrian was very helpful & informative through out. And a pretty girl served items keenly. Music was trendy.

~ Cucumber and Daikon Salad. Refreshingly pickled and crunchy.

~ Jidori Egg Chawanmushi. 
I loved this so much! Soooooo flavorful and delicate texture. This includes shrimp and bok choy plus a hard item at the bottom. It is served along with a wooden spoon and my chawanmushi was very warm. That was nice. I would definitely want this again.

~ Shimofuri Hamachi and Jalapeño Pepper. 
No comment other than nicely plated. It is served with olive oil yuzu shoyu.

~ Shinjuku. 
Yes yes yes! This specialty roll is snow crab and avocado topped with torched A5 wagyu beef. Awesome. I like flames on my beef. So cool. This is my other favorite. Also, I loved the dipping soy sauce small dish that accompanied as well. It was so pretty! *hearts*

~ Toriteba Karaage.
These chicken wings are irresistibly tasty! The memories were an explosion of epic proportions for my taste buds. So good! Is it from the shiso salt? I savored every bite before remembering the spicy mayo. 

~ Smoked tofu & tomato.
This was my special surprise adorned with tiny flower petal. I was told that this item is from Michelin One Star Omakase. I felt so special. Thank you!!! First time ever having tiny orange flower petals to dine upon, and the tomato was very soft and light with tofu invisible to the eye. I appreciate the time and skillfulness.

~ Wakadori chicken karage.
Nice crunch and big pieces of chicken. 

~ Roppongi.
No comment. This is a specialty roll which consists of magruro, hamachi, snow crab, salmon, and avocado that is wrapped with cucumber. Nice presentation.

~ Sake Black Cod & Sake Salmon. Salad in the center.
Nicely grilled and delicious.

I didn't have time for dessert so maybe next time I hope to enjoy Mr. Japanese American Chef's homemade mochi and sesame ice cream!
author: Andrea S.

description:
Stumbled upon this great find by yelping it.
Loved the Saba karaage, chicken karaage, egg custard dish.  My team loved their bento boxes.

This place is excellent quality and Michelin guide!
Price was reasonable but taste and quality was up there.

I love great finds like this.  Authentic Japanese run chefs with great value for high quality fare.

I'm returning!
author: Mary Ann K.

description:
This is by far my favorite Japanese restaurant in San Francisco.  

The wait staff are friendly, the environment is cozy, and most imporantly, the food is of the highest quality.  

Items I recommend:
- thinly sliced lotus root chips + wasabi dip (excellent appetizer for the table)
1/2 dozen oysters (I recommend the uni + roe + quail egg $10 upgrade to add a unique kick to your otherwise already fresh oysters)
- Roppongi roll (this roll is mixed sashimi wrapped in cucumber - very refreshing & no carbs!)

Thank you Okane, for always an excellent dining experience!  I will be returning again, soon.
author: Colette C.

description:
ehh, not super impressed by okane. actually quite disappointed.. i dined at omakase maybe 1.5 years ago and was also not super impressed, so maybe its just this family of restaurants.  came here for girls night and to celebrate a birthday on a monday - the restaurant was pretty dead - half full, but it took a while for our food to arrive though our order was pretty straightforward.

we got a special - chu toro tataki, and that was probably the best thing. other items included: karaage chicken (wayyy overfried), the miso cod, chawanmushi, and 2 rolls. the rolls were probably the last impressive of the whole bunch - thoroughly lacking in flavor and fell apart easily, although i didnt even try the steamed egg.  we dont drink on girls nights anymore, so dinner for 4 plus tax and tip was $120 - not terrible, but also not great.

anyway - i would maybe give okane another shot in terms of the nigiri items, but other than that, no thanks..
author: Christina L.

description: This is a nice Japanese restaurant. I had unagi donburi. Was okay. Nothing special- the bento boxes looked like a better deal for $14 than the donburi ($15). But overall I can recommend this place. Nice Cosy joint.
author: Anuran C.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night at 8pm with no reservations and was able to get seated immediately. I really enjoyed the ambiance of Okane - everything is very clean and modern and the dim lighting gave it a very cozy romantic vibe. 

We ordered:
- Okane handrolls
- Nigiri: Amaebi, tomago, ankimo, toro
- Agedashi tofu

All of the sashimi here was really fresh, especially the amaebi and toro. The okane handroll was just okay - I liked the uni it was topped with but the salmon skin was a tad too much. It would have been much better with fresh salmon instead.

Service here was really good, the waiters were very attentive and professional. 

Overall I thought Okane was a very pleasant dining experience with good food and drinks. Great spot for a casual low-key dinner.
author: Angela K.

description:
I feel like this place is the epitome of SF dining. Beautiful, expensive, a bunch of hip articles written about it to generate hype. And not particularly delicious.

We made reservations for brunch on Saturday at 11. There were already a bunch of people in the quiet, spacious restaurant. We tried the pork set and the veggie set menu, plus the abalone congee. To be honest, I'm pretty sure my favorite thing was the abalone porridge, or the veggie tempura. But it's hard to get rice and fried vegetables wrong. The items in the set menu plates were all just so-so. The pork belly was tough, the egg was straight-out-of-the-fridge cold, the chicken soup had no depth (and the chicken was tough too).

Would not come back, would not recommend. A plethora of tasty alternates in SF.
author: Jenn W.

description:
Was in San Francisco for two days and craved some last minute Sushi. This place was open for lunch on Sunday so I decided to pop in. The rolls were 5 Star fantastic. I got both of their Salmon rolls, one topped with unagi and the other topped with tuna. The unagi was so perfectly cooked it quite literally melted in your mouth.

I would give this place five stars except for the completely overpriced let down of of the chef's seasonal selection of the shashimi. 30 dollars, 8 pieces, I thought I was about to get the best shashimi of my life at that price point. The salmon sashimi was very good but the other three fish selections were no where near what I would expect to get at that price point and on such a premiere menu item.

Save yourself the money, only get the rolls. You'll have a five star experience
author: Joseph B.

description:
Food is 3.5 stars.

Service 1.5 stars. 

Prices are $23 for a sushi roll and one miso soup.

Ambiance is 3 stars.

55 minutes from sitting to getting food!  

Summary: over priced typical Soma joint!
author: Mark K.

description:
A and I went for brunch this weekend and had our expectations met. I made a reservation for 10AM (opening time) assuming we would need it because its SF and you need reservations everywhere but we were the only people in the restaurant through the end of our meal. This was surprising since Okane is buzzy as the more casual little brother of Omakase but I guess its in an odd part of town.

Anyways, we arrived on time and were sat promptly. The hostess explained the menu to us including the 4 set meals as well as the a la carte options which was thoughtful service. I decided on the Megumi set ($25) since it included sushi and A had the Miyabi set ($22). Keep in mind, the prices are $2 higher in the restaurant than online. We did not have anything to drink but water though their Sake list seems legit so if we come back for dinner, maybe we will check that out. While we were waiting for our food, we noticed how beautiful and simple Okane is. It seems very modern with a ton of natural light from the windows. Everything down to the chopsticks (which were the most natural-feeling ones we have ever used) seems well thought-out. Note that Okane shares bathrooms with Omakase next door and that the bathrooms are, befitting of a Michelin Star restaurant, beautiful and smell AMAZING. Weird observation for a bathroom, I know, but I really want to know what air freshener they use because I need it in my apartment like now.

Our food arrived so I stopped pondering the restaurant and took my obligatory Yelp pictures. We were started out with Miso Soup, Salad and Pickles which were as expected and then our sets arrived. Both of the sets were plated BEAUTIFULLY and are instagram-ready. Our waiter explained each dish to us and we got to work! I won't go into details about each dish in each set but everything was good, nothing spectacular. I would say my main disappointing options in the Megumi set were the Temarizushi (Sushi Spheres) and the Onsen Tamago (eggs in hollandaise). The sushi tasted gritty to me and had an odd flavor. The Tamago I couldn't figure out how to eat. From A's Miyabi set, I think the Smoked Salmon wasn't great. Most of the other items both sets were decent. The amount of food was perfect since we were full but not stuffed.

I was a bit disappointed as I have wanted to come to Okane for a while but from what I understand, brunch is a newer offering so they may still have some kinks to work out. I definitely want to come back for dinner before passing final judgement but I think for the price, brunch was underwhelming.
author: Carrie W.

description:
Came by for lunch the other day while working down in the SOMA area. 

Started off with the Chicken Karaage bento box that the owner suggested and it was okay. Chicken was on the saltier side, a tad over-fried, and not super duper fresh. It was good. The side salad was light and decent. The miso soup was okay, a tad salty. The side of spinach, fish cake, and grilled salmon were excellent! ...reminds me of my time visiting Tokyo! :)

As the bento box was merely a large snack, decided to complement the lunch with the Shinjuku roll which was excellent. (All the rolls are Subway stops in Tokyo?!?) The Shinjuku roll had real snow crab topped with A5 Wagyu Beef which was excellent and the highlight of the meal! I'm super glad that I ordered this! The roll was merely a light snack!

Service was very friendly and cordial by the staff. 

It seems like despite trying their best to be a traditional Japanese restaurant, they have some Americanized influence here.

~$49/head after tax and tip for lunch.
author: Derek S.

description:
We have been here a few times, and each time we enjoyed the food and service.
