The sashimi dishes were delicate and fresh. I never get full on just sashimi, so I am glad to see a variety of small eats on the menu. 

The fried chicken is a must. and the tea rice bowls are just enough to satisfy. 

Love this addition to the neighborhood!
author: Mimi T.

description:
I still haven't been to the fancier Omakase next door, but one recent evening after work, I ventured toward this otherwise desolate area of SoMa to give its casual cousin a try. If you've ever been to this part of Townsend after 6PM, it's a bit of a ghost town except for a few locals carrying home their groceries from Trader Joe's nearby. The dimly lit Okane had maybe two other customers when I asked for a table and immediately perused the surprisingly comprehensive menu full of izakaya-style small plates. There were two sushi chefs ready for business at the counter, but business continued to be pretty slow that evening (photo: http://bit.ly/1OgrWXq).

I decided to try one of their specialty rolls, the $15 Roppongi, which decoratively combined maguro, hamaichi, snow crab, salmon, and avocado into a filling wrapped by thinly sliced cucumber in a coil-like fashion (photo: http://bit.ly/1YcaWqM). I thought it was going to be like a rainbow roll, but it actually turned out to be a healthier variation since there was no rice. It tasted so fresh I didn't miss it, and it was complimented by generous slices of fresh ginger (photo: http://bit.ly/1QTEZOi). I decided to follow this up with the $8 Jidori Egg Chawanmushi, a custardy home-style favorite that they gussied up with fresh shrimp and sauteed bok choy (photo: http://bit.ly/1rxDdxz).

It was quite tasty since it reminded me of what my mom used to make if I was a very good boy. I finished off my meal with the $12 Assorted Chicken Skewers, which was actually two skewers of chicken thigh pieces alternating with green onion accompanied by a tsukune meatball, all of it marinated with yuzu kosho (photo: http://bit.ly/1rZgo6G). It was tender and meaty, perfect bar bites. Truth be told, I could have ordered another plate of something, but I was going north of $40 when I had the intention of being a bit more budget conscious. I liked it though and will bring Jamie W. with me next time, so we could try even more dishes.

FOOD - 4 stars...creative, fresh takes on familiar Japanese small plates
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...dark with a local Tokyo neighborhood vibe, casual but not too casual
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...kind enough
TOTAL - 4 stars...an oddly placed izakaya but close enough to me so I'll take it
author: Ed U.

description:
I caught up with a South Bay friend on a Friday evening. He doesn't quite appreciate how difficult it is to get a table in SF and I tried to find the best option available for prime dinner time at the last minute. Okane is what I came up with.

Even though the time we wanted was not available on OpenTable, the hostess was very kind to accommodate us when I asked nicely over the phone. We arrived at 7:30 and were seated at a cute two-top near the entrance. 

The menu is more izakaya style but also has a decent selection of sushi and sashimi. We shared 3 items for dinner: Beef Sukiyaki, Salmon sashimi, and Ginza Roll (shrimp tempura, avocado, cucumber, topped with torched hamachi, jalapeno, blue fin tuna). I was pleasantly surprised that it ended up being enough food for two hungry people.

The sukiyaki seemed highly recommended by some Yelpers but it was truly a disappointment. I do not think I'm a sukiyaki expert by any means but I do love this dish. The beef and overall flavor of the broth was good; however, I did not like the seaweed and the noodles were terribly soft and broken.

The Ginza Roll and Salmon sashimi were good; I've had better at the same or lower price point (Elephant Sushi anyone?).

One of the awesome things about Okane is that there is ample free (after 6) street parking in the neighborhood, which is such a luxury in SF. This is a solid Japanese option in SOMA.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Okane is the izakaya/sushi sister restaurant to Michelin-starred Omakase. I went to Omakase during its first month of opening and loved it, but I immediately realized it wasn't a place to frequent other than for special occasions.

Therefore, I was more than excited for Okane to open. I dined here back in February and was very impressed with their Agedashi Tofu - it was super gooey, melt-in-your-mouth, with a light ponzu sauce. Other favorites included Hokkaido Uni ($15/per pair) and the Shinjuku Roll ($25) - topped with A5 Wagyu for 7 pieces.

Tonight, we dined here again since we were in the neighborhood and were reminiscing their amazing tofu. We ordered it again and while it was good, it wasn't as gooey and mind-blowing as the last time. We made a note to the staff and they were so kind and immediately took it off our tab, asking what made it better last time. I can certainly appreciate when the staff takes the time to take your comments and thoughts into consideration.

We again had the Shinkuku roll and it was as good as last time, if not better. We also opted for some misc nigiri such as the Domestic Uni ($10/pair), Ikura, Sake, and Kanpachi. The domestic Uni from Maine was no comparison to the Hokkaido. Very medicore and less flavorful and creamy than Hokkaido's. The udon was pretty standard- I would've liked a few slices of meat, even if the entree cost a few dollars more. Just udon with soup and an egg is pretty bland.

Service is solid - the staff all share duties and frequently come to check on you and refill your drinks, never really going unattended.

Overall I like Okane for a casual night out or for craving any sort of Japanese dish- they really have a pretty good variety of foods on their menu, from noodles and rice dishes to nigiri/sushi and cooked dishes.

The ambiance is inviting but spacious and pretty casual. This spot in SOMA is especially parking-friendly (metered/street as well as a lot next door).
author: Veronica S.

description:
Cute, uncrowded spot on a Friday night. Great for dates! 

Ordered the kara-age, yudofu (the portion is "yuuuuge"), udon w/egg, and salmon aburi. Be warned that the salmon aburi is like, 4 tiny pieces of sashimi with a tiny slice of avocado with each. 

It's best to try this place tapas style and order a bunch of small plates to share. The food and service is great, definitely a solid place for non-crazy expensive Japanese food!
author: Susan L.

description:
Not bad...I like the name! Took me a second to locate this place. Turns out it's right next door to Omakase, which I luv. Sharing the same restrooms. 
Okane Is different, walk in and it's immediately the chef section. Tables are on the left. We ordered lots of nigiri, ankimo, sushi rolls, scallops and sashimi plate. Loads of uni, 4 orders to be exact(it's a small portion). Ran out of oysters so we couldn't do shooters ={ ordered unfiltered sake and 2 bottles of wine. Turns out we know one of the chef next door, so he gave us some yummy sake to try (gold dragon!!!) it's a fun place, young servers who are very attentive.
author: Vee V.

description: I got to go from this place. I ordered the Shinjuku roll, but it looked nothing like the pics people posted. My "torched" A5 wagyu beef looked overcooked. My Uni from Hokkaido was just so so. Look at photos for reference.
author: Kosmo Z.

description: Absolutely love Okane! The people are great, the food is so fresh, and the atmosphere is intimate. Definitely the best place to eat in the neighborhood.
author: Aleksandra G.

description: Food was good but not exceptional.  Service was the worst. The waitresses kept coming to clear our plates even when we were not ready and rushing us to finish dishes which were not empty. We couldn't even eat slowly to enjoy our meal. With a party of 5, 20% was included.
author: K L.

description: One of my favorite spot in sf. So lucky that this place is right cross street my place. My everyday go to! The beef sukiyaki is a must try, all the indigents are very fresh. Spanish wiz sesame sauce is also my favorite. Rolls are all very delicious, not like the cheap Americanized kind.
author: Yuhan Z.

description:
I had a string of eating at subpar to average sushi restaurants in SF and was really starting to get discouraged. Thank goodness for Okane! 

I hear Okane has the same fish supplier as the supposedly fancier Omekase next door(I have them bookmarked but haven't been yet) and the fish is super fresh and awesome.

Live Uni had a rich, sweet yet briny flavor and soft buttery melt in your mouth texture.

Ginza roll and Akihabara roll were both tasty, both had a generous portion of fish and were full of flavor. I hate when sushi rolls all taste nondescript and similar and this was not the case at Okane.

Chicken karaage was decent. I wish the chicken pieces were cut up a little smaller because it's hard to eat a giant piece of fried chicken while trying to not burn your mouth and strew fried chicken bits everywhere. I also wish it came with some sort of creamy/spicy dipping sauce to cut some of the dryness.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
It's a small restaurant near Mission Bay. It has some bar seating but I would definitely recommend making a reservation to ensure you have a spot when you arrive. The service is reliable and for the most part attentive. 

Came here for Sunday brunch where they were serving "breakfast sets" for meals. My friend and I ordered the Miyabi and Megumi sets. The "buta kakuni" (stewed pork belly) could have been a bit softer. All in all, the presentation was nice and the food itself stands apart in quality and taste.

If you are looking for a similar lunch set place, there is YAYOI in Palo Alto if you happen to be in South Bay.
author: Lester U.

description:
Fantastic quality. Fantastic service. Go.

They share the same hot kitchen as Omakase. The Shinjuku roll is so tasty. They have Fresh Uni but it's not on the menu; also, not always available. Fresh fish shipment comes in on Tuesdays and Thursdays. Make sure to call and ask them to reserve some for you. The Saba Karage is also done beautifully. 

I'd definitely give this place a shot. Great service, great quality, and fantastic execution.
author: Marlene T.

description:
Which of y'all snitches told 'em I was coming? How'd they have Parliament, Tupac x K-Ci x JoJo, Lauryn Hill, Big Pun, AND Humpty Dance(!) cued up the moment I walked in? But they didn't play 8 Ball & MJG; I might've had to go full whitechick* dancing on top of the bar #makinitrain napkins everywhere.

Deece scottie ippin dishes with a few novelty items unfound at other izakayas. Classyish-yet-casualish atmos but NOT for purists / traditionalists bc music. Dope af jams though.

(-_^) Wakadori Chicken Karaage $9
Dat surprisingly nice side salad doe.

(-_^) Spinach W Sesame Mousse $7
"Strong to the finich cause I eats me spinach."

(-_^) Anago Tempura $18
Unique but tastes kinda #basic.

(-_-) Shimofuri Shiromi (Parmesan Sashimi) $22
Not as weird as I'd hoped.

I'd return if I was nearby, but I wouldn't seek this place out... unless I had my #dancingmachine shoes on! #holla

*You never go full whitechick. ;p
author: Dan B.

description:
Came for a early dinner on a Friday with no reservations and was able to get a table right away. Place is smallish but still a lot of table options if you are a group of two. The place is sleekly decorated but not overly done. There is a small bar counter where the chef is preparing the dishes. 
The menu is a little overwhelming with so many options of veggies, beef, fishes, sushi, noodle rice dishes. Luckily we had a great staff that helped us settle some dishes. We went with the delicious live uni (special of the day),yu dofu a clay pot, beef sukiyaki, roppongi roll, nori chazuki, and aji tataki. 
The live uni was obviously fresh and so delicious, and impeccable plate display. The tofu in clay pot was pretty plain and healthy served with kelp and seaweed - nothing special just plain with some side sauce. The beef sukiyaki was amazing and so flavorful - a bit on the salty side but in all the right ways. Roppongi roll was great because it has cucumber instead of rice rolled around the fish so it was a nice alternative. The nori chazuki was rice with soup - it was good and hearty for such a cold night. The Aji tataki stole the show. They took an entire little aji fish, gave us the meat as the sashimi, then deep fried the skeleton for us to eat the end.  It was so amazing! Deep fried aji bones for the win. It was so crisp and flavorful, we ate the whole thing including the head which we weren't sure if we were supposed to keep eating but we did it anyway. I love the zero waste involved. 
Great spot and I'd def recommend it.
author: Veronica L.

description:
It's Japanese diner style food. But given this is America, you can get all sorts of izakaya in one shot. It is not as good as that underground spot in Time Square theatre district (Sake Bar Hagi), but this being San Francisco, it's good, very good in fact.

A perfect spot to take your little ones. They have a good reservation system. You can get in and out easily. The children were tired so it's nice to be seated ahead of the reservation time by 20 minutes. Strength is their sashimi, and misc. bar food that mix well together. Monkfish liver is very fresh. Nigiri is on the spot tender and soft and fresh. Rolls are well done. Sukiyaki is light and airy, perfect for sharing. Grilled cod is rich and flavorful and is as good as you can get on this side of the coast. Chawamushi was bland and watery, worse than I could have made at home, so I'd skip that and go to Ame (the Michelin star restaurant in SoMa) for that (it's really the best of the best, even better than Yuzuki so no need to get it here). Salad is a bit too salty and soggy.

Karage and chicken skewers are quite a hit among the children. Which is to say, this is not a great place for adults who want a fancy Japanese meal but it's excellent if you want to drink a beer and watch the children go crazy. 

I really would have wished for it to be higher end, only because a real exciting izakaya place ought to offer something you just can't get anywhere else. I think it's very good for what it is. It's marked a return place when you need to be gentle to your wallet and you want to go eat quickly and then leave. So this is where the star rating is aligned with the quality of the food and not aligned with its affordability (which is a solid 4) and convenience (which is a 5). 

All things considered, not a date place, a great family (Japanese) diner with popular food items. Inexpensive, with ample parking, and a perfectly good place for friends to gather (won't break the bank).

The restaurant is very efficient. It is powered by a newly minted Michelin star restaurant next door. It's very well staffed. They treat children well. It's very affordable. It's got a huge variety. But for a great new restaurant to stand out and capture the audience, it needs some oompth (think Volta on Mission), or je ne sais quoi (think An Japanese in Japantown) . Sadly, Okane lacked both.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Nothing gets me more excited than when a new restaurant opens up, especially a Japanese one. I could eat Japanese food all day, every day for the rest of my life...if I was rich. But, we all know that legit Japanese food doesn't come cheap. And by "legit", I mean the type that won't give you the Hershey squirts from all dat orange bukkake sauce. 

How can I satiate my Japanese food craving while being mindful of my food expenditures? Go for lunch...specifically, weekday lunch. Lunch items tend to be less expensive and booze is out of the question when you have to return to work afterwards. Though I've been called a "church girl" at work (wtf?!) so maybe a couple of sake bombs will show them who I really am! *Muaahaaahaaa*

My co-worker and I went to Okane (same owner as Omakase next door) for lunch yesterday. Luckily, we came early and beat the lunch rush. They've only been opened for a couple of days and they were pretty packed by the time we left at 12:30 pm.  

Okane is an izakaya restaurant (Japanese tapas). The menu is quite extensive - they have everything from agedashi tofu, chawanmushi, karaage, yakitori, tataki, sukiyaki, donburi, udon to sushi. Their lunch menu and dinner menu is pretty similar except that they don't offer the bento boxes at dinner. They also offer omakase at the sushi bar ($80?). Beer, sake, and wine only.

We started out with the Jidori Egg Chawanmushi ($8): http://bit.ly/1Pntwfs. The jidori egg gave the custard a brighter yellow hue than usual. Loved the silky and lush texture but it needed a touch of salt or soy for flavor. Although the shrimp tempura was perfectly crunchy and airy, I prefer the traditional steamed shrimp. The bok choy was an odd garnish and made one of the tempura pieces soggy.

I ordered the Shokudo Bento Box w/ chicken karaage as my protein ($14): http://bit.ly/1OCsJUz. It was accompanied with a beautiful medley of other items: shiozake, marinated kelp, fishcake, tamago, japanese pickles, rice, and miso soup.

The miso soup was too salty for me so I just picked out the tofu and seaweed to eat but my co-worker enjoyed it. My barometer of a good Japanese restaurant is their rice. The short-grain rice was sticky and had a good chew (not mushy). For functionality purposes, I would have preferred the rice in a bowl. I'm a messy eater to begin with so it was hard to eat rice off a wooden board with chopsticks without flinging some into my hair. Told you, I'm messy af.

The chicken karaage was nicely crisp and tender but it was a little dry and I didn't taste much garlic and ginger flavor. Slurp Ramen in Chinatown has my favorite karaage to date. The other items refreshingly and subtly rounded out the meal. Save the tamago (sweet Japanese omelet) as a "dessert". Portions are appropriately Japanese sized. If you have a big appetite, you'll probably still be hungry after the bento box.

Service was cordial and prompt since we were the first customers. It slowed down as they got busier though. 

The dining area is minimalistic and zen with wooden furnishings and a wall of Japanese noh masks. There's only one large high top for 8 people, so it's recommended to come in a party of 2-4 people. 

Easy street parking. 

Since we went to Okane for lunch and were being mindful of the bill, I didn't get to sample as much of the menu as I wanted to. What we had, however, was pretty solid and was approved by my Japanese co-worker. 

An izakaya meal is not a true "izakaya" meal without sake and beer flowing so for round two, let's let our hair down and get a little ratchet - sake bomb time?
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
As the sister restaurant of Omakase, Okane is just as satisfying and a little cheaper.

My favorite by far was the Salmon Skin hand roll. With a scoop of Uni on top to complete the ikura and salmon skin crunch, this hand roll is the best version I've ever had. I almost wanted to order another.

The fish of course was just as fresh- my friend even ordered a second set of Uni just for herself . The udon (only $8) had a very savory yet not salty broth, which I appreciated.

For the end of the meal, I highly recommend getting the black sesame ice cream. So unique, wonderful flavor, and not overwhelmingly sweet. I plan on ordering that every visit!

All in all, on the pricier end still, but in terms of Japanese cuisine, Okane is worth every penny.
author: Kristi L.

description:
This place is a bit pricey, but the food is amazing! It had some very interesting options that I definitely recommend.
You won't regret getting the Vegetarian Bento Box and the Vegan Donburi in the lunch menu.
The fried Lotus Root Chips and Agedashi Tofu are some of the fried delights you could go for, in the dinner menu.
This is one of the best Japanese restaurants, I have been to, in San Francisco.
author: Karthik Vasishta R.

description:
My friend and I were in the area and we're looking for a good lunch spot. Opened our trusty Yelp app and up popped Okane. We grabbed a couple of seats at the bar and chef Rico acknowledged us and took our order while recommending a few of his freshest fish picks of the day. We had hamachi toro, Kobe beef and the creamiest Hokkaido uni. All were great!
Our server Cindy recommended a couple glasses of sake that paired well with our meal. We could've drank more but it was only lunch time ;( Service was awesome and the decor was clean and inviting.

We will be back.
author: Liz N.

description: Loved this place! Every roll I tried was delicious and unique. Fish was fresh, ambiance was pleasant, and restaurant was very clean!
author: Mrs M.

description: I should have been suspicious, given the name of the restaurant: "Money". We had lunch at this restaurant on Father's Day. If you have ever been to Japan, don't waste your time eating here. The food is terrible and has little to do with Japan. The restaurant also made no mention of serving its more expensive dinner menu at lunch, and when we asked we were defensively told it was because it was Father's Day. To the restaurant, I guess that meant they wanted to use the opportunity to charge more. We would have been okay with it, had the food not been such a joke. Many of the ingredients were Chinese, that we would not normally see in Japan except maybe in Chinese restaurants. The waitresses, who were Japanese, seemed embarrassed to have come across people who seemed to know what they were (supposed to be) eating. Almost $200 for five people, no drinks, at lunch. Don't bother.
author: Craig F.

description: Went here with my friend not too long ago and thought the food was pretty good. I'm allergic to seafood yet the service here was great in accommodating my food preferences! Shoutout to the waitress Laila who recommended non-seafood dishes for me to try! Would definitely come back again :)
author: Nicole C.

description:
Food and ambiance is a little on the flashy side, and overall food and experience was a little overpriced. Overall a decent place, but nothing that would draw me back.

I read the reviews about this place being the sister restaurant of the one Michelin star Omakase next door, and figured the quality must be top notch, with the difference being in the level of service. OpenTable showed openings, so I came here for an early dinner. However, only bar seating was available, and any open tables were being held for reservations (one lady had the same ideas as I did, checked OpenTable but booked a reservation 10 min before arriving).

Chicken skewers showed all the marks of being grilled, but came out lukewarm. Karaage was oversized and a bit hard to eat. Sashimi and rolls were pretty fresh, cuts were a little on the thinner side.
author: James S.

description:
It's our first time here and it's amazing, Great service and great food, but better to have a reservation. There's a line to wait.
All of the fish served was fresh and delicious, good place for small group people enjoy the delicious food.
author: May F.

description: Went there for dinner totally randomly and was pleasantly surprised at how delicious and fresh everything was and how quickly we were able to be seated.  Will be coming back.
author: Diana A.

description:
WOW!!! JUST WOW! That was, by far, the best authentic sushi I have ever had. The freshness, the quality, the utter perfection of every single piece of sushi that was served was like nothing I had ever had before. The head chef here is Lee-San and Kent is the master manager. Their roles might be great but their Omakase style sushi is by far the most amazing Omakase you will ever have. For those who don't know, "Omakase" is basically the chefs selection of hand crafted sushi that he makes on the spot. Lee-San is a master at this. No sriracha or spicy mayo or soy sauce necessary. Just trust the man, he's the best in all of SF. The service and the staff is amazing as well, all kudos go to Kent, the manager master. I can't say enough good stuff about this place so I will just end with this...

Lee-San is like an artist, and sushi is his canvas. Trust him, try his Omakase style sushi, your taste buds will thank you!
author: Mike B.

description: Excellent food, quick service especially at lunch, the notice chips were incredible, the rolls are exceptional and us a shame he buttery soft and fresh... Prices are a little steep but lunch services quick
author: S D.

description: Good eats, nice servers. It opened relatively recently so they're still working out a few snags but whatevs. Highly recommend the udon.
author: Yesenia V.

description: Been twice this past month - quality of the fish seems high, service is great, and it's a pleasantly casual atmosphere - perfect for a date
author: Noah M.

description: Great food, fresh. A nice place in all respects. Parking was a pain, not their fault though. Like most decent sushi places it can cost a pretty penny. But, if you are in the market for fresh and a variety of plates give them a try. They were having issues with the beer tap. Try the uni and wagyu roll.
author: Jaymes C.

description: From start to finish, our meal was superb. Ginza and Shibuya rolls were my favorites. The karaage was amazing. Tip: ask for spicy mayo on the side to dip the chicken (extra $1 charge). Just amazing.
author: Tal A.

description:
4.25/5- Rounding up for amazing service and the awesome dessert
Very happy there's a wonderful sister restaurant to Omakase right nearby. 

Came in for a Friday dinner with a friend. The service we received was on par with a Michelin star restaurant. Pretty sure the two restaurants share a managers or something because the team here is very well trained. Our waiter didn't miss a beat and was extremely professional.

I got the Omakase and my friend and I shared a Shibuya Roll
-The Shibuya Roll was alright. Pretty good and filling. If you're looking to get a filling meal for cheap, try the roll, otherwise the menu has better alternatives.

For the omakase I got:

1) Bluefin Tuna Poke: So good. To be fair I love strong acidity and this poke brought it.
2) Shimaaji and Salmon Belly sashimi: Salmon belly was really nice and fatty.
3) Nigiri Plate 1 w/ Halbut, Kanpachi, Yellowtail, and some sort of belly (I forgot to take a photo so I can't remember the last one.)
4) Nigiri Plate 2 w/ Golden Eye Snapper, Kohada, Hotate, Seared Mackerel.
5) Nigiri Plate 3 w/ Toro and Uni
6) White Sesame Ice cream

The fish was all good quality. About as good as you'd expect from a nice fusion place. For less than $100, I was pretty happy. The Toro and hotate, seared mackerel, and salmon belly were all especially good. However my favorite part of the meal was the white sesame ice cream. I haven't had white sesame flavor before and it was so thick and rich without being too sweet. I could eat it forever.

Overall, really enjoyed my meal here. While there are better omakases out there, this is a good compromise if your friend is looking to have some options.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Don't order online if you want to save time - you might as well walk in and order. You will end up waiting the same amount of time. 

I ordered online, waited 20 min, and now have been standing here for 15 min.  No food yet. 

I didn't one star it because if I have time I enjoy this place for a sit down lunch. Solid sushi.
author: Les I.

description:
I think the Kaisen donburi (sashimi over rice) at Okane is my favorite lunchtime meal in SF and get it atleast weekly when I'm in town.  The cuts of various fish are always fresh and generous so Okane has never disappointed.  My wife prefers rolls and always goes for the Akihabara rolls on each order.

Typically we order take out but have eaten there a few times, the food is always excellent but the service could be a little slow at times.  Still, with how consistent the food is, I've gotta stick with five stars because every meal is always enjoyed whether dine in or carry out.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Ate here twice. Loved it both times.

Really solid Japanese restaurant.

Some of our favorites:
- Saba karaage: perfectly fried
- sliced hamachi with jalapeño
- shibuya roll: light but tasty because of the shiso leaf
- harajuku roll: fried lotus chip is perfect
- udon: savory but not overly salty

Everything we had was pretty good. We ordered the chawanmushi too, it took longer than the estimated time and was kinda plain. Not the worst thing in the world but I'd skip it. Also tried to order a rice bowl but the kitchen got too backed up and I think they forgot the order.

When it's busy, it gets a little hectic but otherwise, service is great.

Perfect little spot for date night and close enough where we can drive to. Plenty of parking on the weekends!
author: T L.

description: Great spot in mission bay. Came here with the bro for a birthday Dinner and it was excellent. Fish is very fresh and dishes very well done. Will be back again!
author: Anant P.

description: Solid high-quality sushi. The chefs know what they're doing, even the rice is perfect. Something about the Decour I can't place it but it feels almost too casual with the way the cashier is placed. It could be very high-end but for some reason it makes itself more casual. Very fresh greens when you get a side salad here, it's not crummy miso dressing, it's fresh and organic. Very innovative food. I'm jealous of the people who work in this area and get to come here for lunch every day. I would try the salmon belly, uni and some of their sake's - beautiful stuff!
author: Lera D.

description: Informal Japanese sushi and sashimi. Great lunch place. Bento box choices , along with some meat dishes too. It's next to the famous Omakase.
author: Sridevi K.

description:
Way place to miss as it is surrounded by SOMA office buildings. This is a sister restaurant to Omakase, right next door (a Michelin rated restaurant). A more casual and affordable affair that shares the same kitchen and some of the same quality fish from Japan or nearby.
Nice medium size restaurant with friendly staff and a comfortable vibe. Service can be a bit slow so make sure to get there attention. Service was taking longer than expected so courtesy miso soup was served. That's a sign of sensitivity to your customers. Ding!  
Oysters are wonderful. The sauce enhances the flavor of the oyster w/ overpowering. Good size with a chewable texture. Very satisfying.
The onigiri is not typical, it is not wrapped in seaweed. The taste is savory but the salmon is cut small and seems hidden within each bite. 
Agedashi tofu was soft with a bit of crunch. 4 sizeable pieces in a delicate sauce with beans and mushroom added for a nice mix. A version of vegetarian tempura.
author: David H.

description: Have always wanted to come here and finally came on a Tuesday night with a reservation. This place has a Michelin star but it's really affordable! We shared their sukiyaki, rolls, and each got a handroll. Everything is superb!! Highly recommend this place if you're looking for good quality Japanese food
author: Joyce L.

description:
Service - 8/10
Food - 8/10
Atmosphere - 8/10
Instaworthy - 6/10

Good for a working lunch but minimal options for vegetarians (as expected from the cuisine choice). However, they're super helpful with substitutions and trying to make the order match your preferences. I'd say it's a little over priced for the quantity but the quality of food is good.
author: Meher G.

description: Decided to try because we heard it's omakase's sister restaurant. Ordered 6 half-shell oysters with extra uni, egg and ikura; a lot of nigiri (Maine uni, toro, amaebi, wagyu beef, hamachi, sake); salmon aburi, salmon & ikura chazuke, notams udon, and more sashimi. And that's more than enough for 3 of us. Wanted to try the live scollops (sold out) and live uni next time! The fish are fresh and the uni and toro are really good.
author: Cate L.

description:
Okane is the sister restaurant to the one Michelin star Omakase next door. It's much more affordable with still high quality fish and other ingredients. 

We ordered salmon sashimi, uni, two salmon rolls, and the sukiyaki. The sukiyaki was my favorite! It was very flavorful and had lots of tender meat. The sushi was good as well. 

Definitely a great spot for casual date night as well as with a group of friends. Service was very friendly and attentive.
author: Sophia H.

description: Service not good. Beef donburi very plain. A bit more expensive than it deserve. Will probably not go again.
author: Lily H.

description: I really like this restaurant. The food is unique and delicious. My favorite is the pork belly. For 4 people it was about $100.
author: Irina M.

description:
Oh the Chef is Japanese so what did we eat? Stuff I've never heard of. Awesome adventure!!!

Hijiki Seaweed. It's warm! The mushroom is divine and the flavor is like no other, it was a deep flavor, almost like tea, but flavorful. Oh did I mention flavor? 

Chawan Mushi wow so good I had to google it. It is egg custard similar to the Chinese steamed dish and they make it so light, you could eat it forever so order more :)

Sake Lees Cured Fish get the cod get the cod get the cod OmG yes that rhymes.

Hokkaido Uni - first in my life ever. It was a smooth flavor bomb, real soft then explodes in your mouth. Yes I would do that again. Yes.

Hamachi Belly Sashimi - also a first also a wow.

My buddy got Chef's Choice Sashimi which had like Golden Eye Snapper. Told you I ain't heard of any of this but she finished all the choices well pleased.

House Made Black Sesame Ice Cream with Okinawan Black Sugar drizzle is actually white in color. If you love the conviction of guilt for eating dessert get an extra order after you finish and punish yourself! Do it! Tell the devil I sent you!

Their cute tea pots and cups top it all for me.
Ask for Jamie she was a doll!

5 stars
author: Leo M.

description:
We came for their Japanese brunch.  I don't think I've found another Japanese set meal place in SF? 

To start, the passionfruit mimosa was nice and tart, and it was a pretty big portion for $10!  The water is served in old Hibiki bottles. 

There are a few a la carte options, but the main focus is the set meals ranging from $18-22 - they look kind of like thalis.  3 of the 4 of us did the Megumi ($22). All come with rice and miso soup.  It was a good amount of food.

1. Gyuniku shigureni: stewed beef with sesame seeds and ginger - sweet soy sauce flavor, caramelized onions
2. Gindara misozuke: miso glazed cod - standard, not over cooked 
3. Onsen tomago: 63 degree egg with hollandaise, truffle oil, asparagus; good poured over the rice 
4. Sushi spheres: salmon, tuna, and ika - cute balls of sushi 
5. Potato salad 
6. Chairmen jako: crispy tiny fish - good on rice

We each got a set meal, but we also added on some other things (good for sharing among 4 people):
1. Kani lobster gohan: crab and lobster rice with lots of butter, good seafood flavor, served in a clay pot. It's good for filling you up
2. Ebitama okonomiyaki: not too much batter, lots of cabbage, with all the usual toppings (bonito, kewpie, nori, okonomiyaki sauce)
3. Beet cured Scottish salmon: weirdly red outside; light beet flavor. The salmon itself is very buttery, but I didn't love this

The space isn't that big, but tables are nicely spaced, and it filled up for brunch on a Saturday.  I'm not sure how dinner is, but I would definitely come back for brunch (the megumi set).
author: Marilyn T.

description: This place is next door to and owned by the same people who own Omakase and Dumpling Time. Dumpling Time is epic. I haven't been to Omakase yet but while eating at Okane they did bring us an order of toro from Omakase to try. The chefs oysters are epic here. All the fish is very fresh and good. I definitely recommend it.
author: Jasper P.

description:
I want to believe they had a bad day.
I had brunch with bf and ordered Miyabi and Megumi.  Rice they served was so dry and old.  I can cook much tastier rice at home with my rice cooker than rice they served.  I asked one of the servers to replace our rice to fresh ones, and she brought the same old dry rice.  Only reason I could think of is they served the rice which was cooked a day ago.  I could not barely eat the rice.
Most of dishes on both of the courses we ordered were either missed or just ok.
Sesame tofu was not creamy as it should be and had no sesame flavor.  I would not go on for other dishes, but I could not finish any of them.
Even worse, they forgot to bring sushi for Megumi and we had to remind them to bring it to us, which was not worth asking for.

Again, given the good reviews of others, it could be one of those bad days for the restaurant.  One bad experience is good enough for me to decide not to come back here, though.
author: Kahori M.

description: Ok, I know I just gave 5 stars to Kuma, but this was especially amazing! Seaweed salad connoisseur, sashimi chef special - such great buttery textures! Best was salmon avocado seared w/ roe, simple yet amazing bursting flavors w/ will of wisdom sake & green tea -- yum!
author: Caroline L.

description:
We made an early reservation on a Saturday night and the place was not full but busy. I can see us coming here often as it is close, convenient, and food is delicious. Right next door is sister restaurant Omakase which we have yet to try. Okane calls themself an izakaya and doesn't just serve sushi so this made it easier for us with the baby.

Service is friendly and attentive. 

Special - lightly seared hamachi belly nigiri - I love this. I am not a huge fan of cold fat in my mouth so the lightly torched belly is perfect for me. so delicious
Special - lightly seared salmon belly nigiri - same as above
ikura nigiri - fresh and delicious
uni
amaebi - heads came fried of course
fried lotus root chips - served with wasabi mayo. we put some lemon on it to cut the grease
steamed clams (minus oysters) - yummy
assorted chicken skewers - thigh and meatball both juicy and delicious
sake and shiso yaki onigiri - baby ate most of this. crispy on outside. only complaint was it didnt hold together
salmon aburi - tasted good but textures were just mushy all around. could maybe use a rice cracker or something crunchy underneath.

We will be back! Glad to have more neighborhood restaurants to try!
author: claudia y.

description: Came here for Sunday prix fixe brunch and the experience was amazing. Had made a reservation on OpenTable, so no wait time for us. Presentation of the food is so beautiful, I almost didn't want to eat it. Favorites were the salmon and the cod.
author: Anna Z.

description:
In case you didn't already know, Okane is the sister restaurant to Michelin rated Omakase next door. For me that was enough of a hook to get me strolling through their doors....lol. Well that and the fact I have been super craving quality sushi  lately. I came to Okane with the mentality of finding really high quality fish with a reasonable price point, and in that regard I believe they met my expectations. I came with a friend and we shared a bunch of nigiri. Among them were the toro, sake, hamachi belly, hokkaido uni, kinmedai, and shima aji. We also split an order of the shinjuku roll which was basically similar to a fancied up California roll but used snow crab instead and was topped with lightly torched A5 Wagyu beef. 

I was really excited to try the toro since this was my first time ordering it coupled by its high price point and rarity. (Don't even get me started on overfishing and sustainability...lol) Anyways, I digress. The toro was ever so slightly torched and visually you could just tell it was a fatty piece of fish by the flesh. I salivated in anticipation. When the toro first hits your tastebuds, you get that immediately recognizable "tuna" flavor but after that is when all comparisons end and the flavor you get is just fatty, creamy goodness. It literally melts in your mouth and if you were blindfolded, you could easily be duped into thinking this was a piece of high grade Kobe or A5 Wagyu beef. You heard of Parmesan Reggiano hailed as the undisputed king of cheeses??? Then Toro has to be the G.O.A.T of sushi....lol. 

We were quite pleased in the quality of all our nigiri, especially in the fish to ride ratio. Whereas most sushi bars might try to skimp on the fish ad cut a sliver of fish that's almost transparent and place it on a mountain of rice, Okane did the exact opposite and cut a generous portion of fish that pretty much blanketed the bed of rice it was placed upon. Our only complaint on the fish was the kinmedai, which we found awfully chewy and almost gristly, not good eats. Our server also neglected to give us individual plates even though we were sharing basically everything. Minus 1 star. In short, Okane is a solid sushi bar worthy of it's big brother's Michelin status. Until you get to try out Omakase, I would suggest Okane as an affordable alternative. I will definitely return.
author: Derrek O.

description: Great new Japanese spot in SOMA for fresh sushi!  Prices are reasonable and service is great! I'm a fan. =)
author: Melanie N.

description: Solid food, but servings are too small for the price. We went to get a second dinner at the grove afterwards. The rice dish and udon were too plain for my tastebuds. Taro chips were good! Karage was also good, but I can get something comparable for less at ramen restaurants.
author: Lisa H.

description:
*** In Short ***

Decent izakaya with okay to tasty dishes, but pricing relative to portions lends to poor value.

*** In Depth ***

I took advantage of that fact that I was In the area for a nearby art exhibition last weekend to come and try Okane while they were still new, and hopefully, not too crowded. Coming in around 8pm without a reservation, my date and I were lucky enough to get seated almost immediately, at the last open table at the time.

Now, I've never been to Omakase, and I'm admittedly not a huge fan of sashimi. However, Okane has branded itself as an izakaya, and I ordered accordingly, for the most part::

* Sake Lees Alaskan Black Cod - I use black cod as a baseline to judge izakayas by, and while theirs wasn't bad, it was lighter in flavor than I would have expected, and not nearly as melt-in-your-mouth tender as I would have liked.

* Toriteba Karaage - A little bland on its own, but very flavorful when paired with the accompanying spicy mayo and shiso salt. But, I mean, these were just chicken wings. Sorry: expensive, chicken wings. For the same price, I could have gone to Hot Sauce and Panko and gotten almost 3x as many wings, that would have been both more flavorful and juicier.

* Chawanmushi - A very, very delicately flavored chawanmushi, compared to the ones I've had in the past. Not to the point of being bland, but given the two things we'd eaten right before, it definitely was on the light side, comparatively.

* Shinjuku Roll - By far the best thing we had that night, and the only thing I'd consider coming back here for. It's basically a California roll (with real crab) with a hefty portion of torched wagyu beef on top. The flavor of the California roll portion was a little more dominant than the beef, but you could definitely taste both. Pricey, at $25 for seven pieces, but more reasonable when considering the components than the other items were.

So, the problem with Okane isn't that the food is bad, because it's not. The problem is that, for the price (we ended up spending $40 per person after tax and tip) and the small portions, I'm expecting the food to be fantastic, if not stellar, and that, these were not. The value just isn't there. If you want a solid izakaya experience, you're better off going to Kiraku in Berkeley for something casual, or Izakaya Yuzuki in the Mission for something fancier.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - It's a brand new restaurant, so accessibility isn't a problem, with plenty of space and accessible tables.

Bathroom - Single, private bathrooms, and quite accessible.
author: Johnny W.

description:
********************** 1491 *********************

   Okane just recently opened in January 2016, I got to check out their lunch and dinner, and I love every dish that we ordered.

  Okane is adjacent to the newly Michelin Starred Omakase next door. A 46-seat place with beautiful and comfortable wooden tables and chairs, even the bowls and plates are carefully paired with the food. Okane opened by the Omakase team, a SoMa Design District neighborhood Izakaya and Japanese share dishes. 

  Chef Jackson Yu, with 18 years of experience from all over the world, and recently earned his first Michelin Star at Omakase. With new chef Shin Aoki (former Kaigetsu) created a menu with dishes that warm your heart and make your belly happy. 

  I truly enjoy coming here, because the GM Justin Goo (former Bar Manager at Alexander's Steakhouse and Gary Danko). Under his management, Omakase and Okane will only get better. Plus I adore one of my favorite servers Quade (former Alexander's Steakhouse SF), he is there at dinner.He's a cutie and a fire cracker, we always enjoy his service. And at lunch, Barry and Molly are both awesome servers. 

   Their omakase starts at $80 for 10 pieces of nigiri, a sashimi course and housemade sesame ice cream which is a bargain. They serve you at the 4-seat sushi bar.  Drinks include Japanese beer, sake and a small wine list, but very reasonable priced. I love the sparkling Brut from France, only $25 per bottle, and we enjoyed the small 300ml Sake bottle too.

- Vegetables Ippin: Cucumber and Daikon Salad, that ShioKombu dressing was so refreshing, my BFF ordered 2!  Aghedashi Tofu, Yo-Dofu Tofu, Grilled Shitake Mushroom, Lotus Root Chips, Bok Choy with Sesame Mousse, were all good.

- Fish Ippin: Grilled Salmon, Hamachi & Jalapeno Pepper and Alaskan Cod, were delicious. I love the Hamachi and the Cod. 

- Meat Ippin: Wakadori Karaage fried young chicken, Beef Skewer, and assorted chicken skewer were all good. The fried young chicken is a MUST TRY here. 

- Rice and Noodles: Salmon and Ikura Chazuke, rice bowl served in savory tea broth was nice. Nori and tea soup, and Udon with soft egg were all on point.

- Rolls: Shinjuku Snow Crab, with A5 Wagyu Beef roll is a MUST ORDER.  I don't like roll but I will eat this roll anytime!

- Sushi and Sashimi: Fresh live Uni, order it when they have it, a MUST! Otoro, Kuroamago, Tai, Kinmedai, Hirame, Aji, and Ankimo Monk Fish Liver, of course. Everything was as fresh and tasty as it gets.

  I've been here a few times now, and I love it here. Lunch menu is smaller but the Bento Box is a good way to try variety of dishes. For dinner, I ran into two OG Yelpers already, Euge L and Wanugee. It's definitely a good place to hang out with friends. Okane simply serves good food and drink, well priced, and great hospitality. 

  Okane is open daily from 11 AM - 3 PM for lunch, and 5 p.m. to midnight for dinner on Fri and Sat, a perfect spot for late night bites and Sakewa!
author: Manda Bear B.

description: Delicious food and amazingly fresh fish! Immensely enjoys our dinner. I would definitely come back.
author: Y K.

description:
Food was good, but I had a really bad experience so that I had to post my first yelp review:
Confusing menu + wrong dish (which we did not order) + order got canceled without notice + ignorant server + cheap disposable plastic fork & spoon + over-charged bill (which we caught) + declined request for a high chair  = terrible dinner
author: QQ L.

description:
If you like quality sushi - definitely check this place out. They are supplied by the same fishmonger as michelin starred Omakase next door, so you know you're getting the good stuff.

Roppongi - super light and refreshing, they've wrapped hamachi, snow crab, salmon, and avo with cucumber. There's no rice in this one and it's a nice change to a traditional sushi roll.

Akihabara - salmon, avo, topped with unagi. Simple, yet super delicious. You can really taste the freshness and quality in the fish.

Uni - They were out of the Hokkaido Uni, so we opted for the Monterrey Uni. One of them had a kind of bitter aftertaste while the other had the creamy, slightly sweet taste you want in a quality sea urchin.

Mackerel Bento - Mackerel is one of those fish that taste super fishy once they've gone past that fresh state. You can totally tell if a sushi restaurant is skimping on quality by tasting their mackerel. In Okane's case, the mackerel was super fresh and not fishy at all. Even one of the girls at our table who hates fishy things remarked at how fresh it tasted.

Chawanmushi - I love a good chawanmushi when made right. This one was silky smooth.. almost custard like. Perfect.

All in all, I'd totally come back, perhaps for an actual Omakase meal?
author: Henry W.

description: Ate here for the first time last night. The hamachi sashimi was fresh, firm, and scrumptious. The small plates were all excellent. Not your usual Japanese restaurant, a little bit of fusion. The lotus root chips came in a large mound, the udon was also a large delicious serving. The Roppongi roll was delicate, visually appealing and good for those avoiding carbs (wrapped in cucumber). Overall really excellent food and service. Just around the corner from the SF Design Center.
author: MJ L.

description:
TLDR :
Ambience : Clean and rustic : 4/5
Service : Polite and fast : 5/5
Food :
Ontama Udon : Nice texture and flavorful, with it had meat : 4.5/5
Assorted chicken skewers : Delicious, wish we could mix and match : 4/5
Hirajuku Roll : Fresh fish with delicious rice : 4/5
Scallop and Blue Fin Tuna Nigiri : Fresh fish with delicious rice, perfect ratio : 5/5


We decided to go to Okane, a sister restaurant and neighbour of Omakase, for early dinner. We got seated immediately by the window. The decor was simple but clean, the wooden blinds gave the place a rustic feel. The service was fast and polite. We started with Ontama Udon, it came with an egg in it. It had perfect texture and temperature. Noodles were perfectly cooked and the broth was delicious and just the right amount. The quantity was generous. We had assorted chicken skewers next, it came with two bbq chicken and one meatball skewer, both done perfectly. I had a slight preference for the meatball, but who doesn't. Usually I find people don't do a good job with chicken and over cook it, it was definitely not the case here. Skwers were delicious. It came with a salad which was fresh. I am not sure what the small white balls on it were. The roll we got was Hirajuku, salmon, avocado, shrimp tempura, topped with tuna, spicy kabayaki and lotus root. For nigiri we decided to get Hotate, the hokkaido scallop and Kuromaguro, the blue fin tuna. Fish was fresh and rice was delicious and the fish to rice ratio was perfect. Overall, I enjoyed Okane a lot. I'll come back to try their brunch sets!
author: Kritika K.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night with the SO expecting a long wait due to the small space. Was able to place a reservation but it wasn't necessary since the location doesn't really scream as an area to stick around in after 8 PM. That doesn't take away from the fact that we had an awesome meal.

On this night we ordered the Fried Lotus Roots, Oyster on the half shell with the fixings, Rice with softly cooked egg, chicken karaage, Chef's Choice Sashimi, Shibuya and Akihabara roll. (We were pretty hungry as you can tell). Unfortunately, they forgot our Lotus Roots but everything else was exceptional. The Karaage was fried on point with a sort of egg batter that was extra crispy. The rice and egg, while a simple dish, was a very elegantly displayed with deep flavors. The rolls were good but I'm partial to ones with lemon slices on it.

Great date night spot without too much wait. Service is friendly and the food is good quality. A place to start your night if you plan to spend an evening out but expect to most likely ride share to and from there as there isn't much happening around that location.
author: Eric L.

description:
Okane is Omakase's more fusion-y, affordable cousin. Located right next door to Omakase, Okane shares many of the fish flown in from Tsukiji for Omakase, with a small sushi bar (4 people). 

Okane also offers omakase for $80 (compare it to Omakase's 100, 150, and 200) but the chefs are obviously not the same as the team at Omakase. Okane's menu focuses more on izakaya dishes, ranging from donburi, udon, yakitori, rolls, to the more traditional nigiri and sashimi. 

My friend and I opted for sushi, the Shinjuku roll (with A5 wagyu!), chawanmushi, salmon aburi, and sukiyaki. Everything was presented beautifully and tasted great; Okane obviously aims for a high-quality presentation and dining experience. I wouldn't necessarily say that the fish was better than what you would find at other high-end sushi places around the city (think Wako, Koo, Kusakabe, etc) but it's definitely on-par. 

The space is beautifully decorated and the service is friendly, albeit a bit more disorganized (I did go within the first 5 days of opening). The price point is on the higher end- I ended up paying about $80/each including tip, which is just about what would you spend at a higher-end sushi place in SF anyways. I would definitely consider Okane to be a worthy addition to SF's izakaya dining scene.
author: Kate M.

description: Sushi was not that impressive (they source their fish separate than Omakase). Not that fresh and rice was too firm. Pricey and underwhelming.
author: Q C.

description:
Decide to grab lunch here with some coworkers, and it was surprisingly good!

The karaage (fried chicken) lunch set was really good. The chicken was seasoned and fried well - not too much batter. The unagi bowl was also delicious - great sauce, tender fish, not too fatty.

The agadashi tofu had a great sauce but had more batter than I like on my tofu. 

Overall a really tasty option for lunch. I will be going back soon!
author: Jaching H.

description: This place is about quality ingredients.  One of my favorite rolls at any restaurant is Shinjuku roll with the snow crab in the middle and waygu beef on top  Haven't had such a creative roll in a while.  Another must order is the Hokkaido Uni which was creamy.  Udon with egg is also good too.
author: Stevezee C.

description:
I absolutely love this place and cannot stop raving about the Omakase team. Chef Jackson from Omakase next door told us about their plans to open Okane a few months ago, so my friend and I were incredibly excited for the chance to finally try it out.

Okane and Omakase source their fish from the same places, so anything you get at Okane is guaranteed to be high quality. Okane's omakase (lower-case) is priced at $80 per person which is pretty reasonable for the great food and service. 

Chef Rico was wonderfully attentive and took great care of us. My favorite dishes from tonight were the impossibly smooth ankimo and beautifully presented amai ebi, but every course we ate was masterfully put together and very flavorful.

The staff are wonderful - they even overheard that it was my birthday and served my sesame ice cream with a cute little candle! It was a very thoughtful and kind gesture, which is a testament to the great people who work there.

I will definitely be back to try more of their izakaya offerings, but you really can't go wrong with the expertise and experience of the sushi chefs here. Okane is a fantastic option for omakase and I highly recommend it!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Japanese inspired brunch. 

What a wonderful concept. Take a japanese menu and serve it in a way you might imagine a japanese person might brunch.

Brunch includes 6 different selections pairing well with each other. Think of it as a bento brunch....a "Brunto"... or perhaps a "Brench" box.

Delicate and deep flavors encourage you to taste all the small dishes.

Now if they could offer matching drinks to take it all down...afterall what is brunch without drinks?
author: Spanky M.

description: I wanted to like this place! The pictures on Yelp were really inviting, but the flavors that I tasted just didn't match up to the price. First off, we got the tartare which was tasty! The Harajuku roll was also yummmy as well! But we got one other roll (which I forgot the name of) - it was wrapped in cucumber instead of seaweed, and although the idea was innovative, the overdose of cucumber drowned out the tastiness of the savory fish inside. But really though. The fish was theeee bomb dot com in that roll!! Lastly, I ordered the Ikura and Salmon rice dish with the hot green tea, and this is where I really felt like I didn't get my money's worth. Yes, I knew it was going to be experimental and probably bland, but I didn't expect it to be thaaaat tasteless. I thought that at least the fish eggs would save the flavor, but meh. I tried to save the flavor with pepper flakes, wasabi and soy sauce, but uguuu, not my cup (or bowl) of tea. Although I enjoyed the first two fish dishes, it was along the pricey end and I was still hungry, so overall, I'm giving this place a three star. The ambiance and decor inside was really nice and Japanese-esque though!! Next time, I think I'll try eating the nigiri sushi rather than the menu items and perhaps my rating with change because the fish here really did taste fresh and savory!
author: Kim N.

description:
Opened in the 1st month of year now rolling with impeccable service n food !!!!
Had a chance to visit over for lunch, n all I cud say tat just drooling over the food.
1st experience with the Izakaya cuisine, but left  flavorful  n delighted .
author: Aby S.

description:
It was okay! I went to Japan as part of my honeymoon and missed the traditional breakfast sets I had every morning, and finally found a place that made japanese style breakfast here in sf!

cute place. service was fast, and good. waiters were attentive. 5 stars for service.

knocking down a star because the food was just alright. i wasn't blown away or anything, but it was ok.. i don't think i'll return brekky here though.
author: Catherine Y.

description: My friend and I came here for lunch because it was close to where I was staying in SoMa. The restaurant is clean, service is good and food is fresh. I ordered the sushi lunch ($19) and it came with a salmon roll and 4 pieces of sushi, miso soup and rice. My friend ordered a tempura bento box and she enjoyed it. There isn't that much selection on the menu but it has a lot of items you would expect a Japanese restaurant to have - sushi rolls, sashimi, bento boxes, noodles etc etc. Pretty standard Japanese restaurant and I would give it 3 stars but +1 star for using good quality fish.
author: Valerie L.

description: Love this spot but don't go on Mondays - gone several times and it's not fresh. Tuesday's and later are good. Yummy menu, great service unless it's slammed. Little pricey but great (when fresh).
author: R B.

description: Place is not very authentic and way over priced. Definitely not coming back and hoping to avoid sushi joints like this one in the future.
author: Soh T.

description:
Really great food and service.

Nigiri was very delicious and quality. A bit pricey but worth it.

There was a roll or two on the specialty list that were not as great as the others.

Only Two beer types to select from but the IPA is not bad.
author: Stan H.

description: The food is consistently good.  I've been here for lunch and dinner.  The sushi is always fresh and perfectly balanced. The quality of the cooked food is also very good.  The only reason I'm giving 4 instead of 5 stars is that the wasabi was not fresh and the service was just okay. It's still one of my favorite Japanese restaurant.
author: Egen T.

description: The restaurant took easily one of the top items off the menu--chicken wings. Unreal and disappointing. Hopefully they change that because their sushi rolls are good but not stand out.
author: Alex C.

description:
3.5 stars but I'll round up because I'm optimistic. It's early and it'll improve with time. I was sooooo pumped for this place.

The food was great if a little pricy. I'm fine with that but the atmosphere was a little off. The location is wonky, and since there are huge windows, you can't really block it out. The ceilings and the window-bar-separators are all office-building standard.

The service was attentive and on point. There was a lot of attention paid to details such as plateware, quality of chopsticks and utensils, etc.

The ceiling and the huge office window looking out onto other offices definitely threw off the ambiance.
author: Victoria C.

description:
More of a 3.5.  Considering the relative lack of good restaurants in SOMA, we were very excited about Okane's opening.  The food was certainly good enough that we'd come back to try some other menu items, but this won't quite become our go-to SOMA restaurant.  We had:
 - Udon (3/5).  Noodles were a little too soft, and the broth was slightly too salty.
- Some salmon and avocado thing (4/5).  This was really pretty good, probably our favorite dish.
- Shrimp tempura (4/5).  Interesting texture for tempura but good and flavorful.
- Chicken skewers (3/5).  Still tastes good but lacks the grilled flavor I expected.

The restaurant itself is pleasant, and the service was great.
author: Simon L.

description: Best place in this area of Soma. Come here all the time for lunch or after work. Recommend the beef sukiyaki with an order of rice.
author: Willie Y.

description:
Came here for dinner before a show- had reservations for 5:30p and walked into a very quiet restaurant with smiles and was swiftly seated. 

The ambiance is a mix of group seating and private tables- high top tables are well situated for a small group, the sushi bar can accommodate 4-6 and some tables for 2 decorate the rest of the space.

Service was friendly, efficient and generous with suggestions and favorites. We debated doing the omakase or menu and opted to walk through the menu and try an assortment of dishes. 

We particularly enjoyed the uni and toro nigiri, awesome Bok Choy with sesame mousse. Started with a bottle of sparkles from Loire valley and finished with a delightful sake.


The grilled sake lees cured cod is amazing, definitely need to try this! It melts in your mouth and is full of delicious goodness. 

Agendashi tofu was ok but nothing special, pieces were too big losing a lot of flavor to the overwhelming tofu texture.

Overall worth checking out! Solid choice, friendly community and yummy foods.
author: Angela D.

description:
oishi!

i love this place so much. it's quite affordable and all the dishes are exquisite while the ambiance is far from stuffy. i especially love the fact that they have various chazuke dishes (love the taichazuke)-- it's hard to find restaurants that have it on their menu, let alone do it right! i also love their uni ippin and kaiseki sushi. really awesome quality of fish and the service is a-ok. one small complaint is that the tables are way too small for the different plates we ordered, and i am super OCD when it comes to table clutter.

the quality of the beef in the sukiyaki was great. it was served in a 1-2 person nabe and was fantastic. the black sesame ice cream was delicious-- dense and creamy yet fluffy and complex. definitely recommended!

itadakimasu!
author: Vanessa D.

description: Nice space with tables and inviting wooden booths with a view of the sushi bar. Had a range of dishes but what really stood out was the Okane handroll. This made my meal with uni and an interesting texture of both the smooth uni and crunchy ingredients I can no longer remember. The sashimi was also fresh, the mackerel and salmon were memorable. I don't normally go for mackerel but here it was fresh and smoky. The vegetarian dishes with tofu and mushrooms were delicate but filling. Service was also great, very satisified.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Starters: 
Yo-Dofu: The tofu seems to be too firm for this dish.  We didn't care for this as much
Cucumber & Daikon Salad:  this was actually very light and refreshing. 
Wakadori Karaage: This was pretty good fried chicken nuggets 

Sushi: 
All of the below fish tasted really fresh and was so yummy. 
Hokkaido Uni: imported 
Kanpachi:
Shiro Maguro
Ginza Roll: This special roll was so good!

This is the 2nd time I've been at this restaurant and both experiences enjoyed the food very much. Will definitely come back again.
author: Mei B.

description:
A-ok, nothing that screams "I'm coming back tomorrow!" Atmosphere - nice and dark, and fairly quiet and empty on a weeknight. Service - friendly and attentive, gave some good suggestions. 

Ah the food. Fried lotus chips - 3.5 - decent, nothing screams wow, I felt the dipping aioli (wasabi?) was the best part. Agedashi tofu - 4 - broth was good, tofu was silly and fried just right. There were a few pieces of veggie tempura on top that I could make out what they were. Again, it's nice but not wow. Omata udon - 3 - good broth, ok noodle, nice onsen egg. Definitely didn't wow me. Salmon chasuke - 3 - at this point I don't know if it's the fact that our table is sharing all this and that's why everything taste so off or it's just me. Like, the tea doesn't taste like tea, the rice and salmon had almost no flavor. The ikura was a good touch in changing the texture but I don't think it was enough foe me to rate it any higher. 

Let's talk seafood. Hokkaido uni - 5 - yum...heaven. Santa Barbara uni -5- great. Salmon toro -5- mmm yah. Kinmedai - 4.5- not a total fan but I can taste that it's definitely fresh. Halibut  - 3.5- good but forgettable. The roll with wagyu beef and snow crab - 3 - good but...I don't quite know how to describe but I wasn't wowed. The live scallop 2-way (nigiri as well as salad) - 3.5 - the nigiri was so small I can barely taste the scallop. Same goes for the salad, like where's the scallop?! I normally love scallop so I was disappointed not to have tasted it more.
author: Lisa Z.

description: Sushi is mediocre at best, rice is hard. We got the fried Ebri head before body(20 mins before) it took 30 mins after we finished to even get the bill. No one ever asked how anything was. We ate here a year ago and it sucked. After eating at their sister dumpling time we thought of giving it a try. HUGE MISTAKE.
author: Seb M.

description:
Mediocre food at best and a lackluster experience.

First off, the food. We ordered two rolls, a tofu dish, and a sashimi plate. The two rolls were ok. I would say the biggest issue was that all the flavor s would muddle together and you end up not being able to taste the fish. The tofu dish was a huge let down. We ordered the Yu-dofu and we felt the chef just gave up. Image four pieces of tofu that tasted store bought, two shitake mushrooms, and some veggies, boiled in water. Yep, that's it. I mean, at least put it in some dashi sauce as it was so bland. The sashimi plate was the complete opposite. All you could taste was the truffle oil and the texture of something soft (fish) and mushy (avocado) - the presentation was very messy too.

Lastly, the experience. The waiter seemed a bit distracted when I asked him questions about the menu. The menu is quite confusing as they try to be fancy with the descriptions and titles. However, every time I asked a question and he answered one, he would begin to turn away and leave. I had to start asking another question for him to stay. This happened three times. When the food arrived, the wait staff would also just drop things off without explaining what they brought. 

Granted, we had some baseline expectations since the sister restaurant has a Michelin star and yelp had 4 stars, but this was a huge letdown, especially for the price of the food.
author: Andy C.

description: After walking into the wrong restaurant, which apparently happens frequently(!), the hostess next door kindly walked me to Okane's entrance.  Food and service were excellent and I am definitely coming back. We had a small feast with the shinjuku, harajuku, and ginza roll which were all amazing. The Saba karaage was a nice change from the more common chicken version. And the salmon ikura chazuke tasted like comfort food. We also had the hotate and uni nigiri which were both really good. Can't say enough good things about this place.
author: Debbie L.

description: Came here last night without reservation, Mario sat us down and gave us some really good recommendation. The food was really fresh and came out perfectly, it's def not your basic Japanese restaurant, the staffs here are so friendly so they made sure you have a wonderful experience. would def come here again!
author: Edison H.

description:
FOOD:
Agedashi tofu (4/5): Good, but nothing super special about it.

Salmon aburi with avocado (5/5): salmon sashimi, avocado AND TRUFFLE?!! 3 of my favorite things in 1 dish, how could I not love it? Thankfully I did love it, but not sure if I would spend $20 for 2 pieces again. 

Harajuku roll (4/5): Made well, fresh fish, and the crispy lotus root was my favorite part!

SERVICE (3/5): 
super super important for a restaurant that is just opening up -- and I thought it was a little less than okay, because the waitress completely forgot to put in our agedashi tofu order. 

Overall -- would come back, but it's a little pricier than the average $$.
author: Amanda C.

description: Compared to Omakase, I find Okane to be a much better value.   Have visited multiple times and tried both raw and cooked dishes and it did not disappoint.   Attentive service was also a plus!
author: Hsiao C.

description:
One of the better sushi restaurants in SF. I would have given five stars for their out of this world, cake like lobster tamago...but they decided to stop making it.

Now it's still got great sushi and a really good rice bowl with sous vide egg but it's a shame they took the most delicious thing on the menu off.

Also, many will be pleased with the addition of truffle oil to just about everything. (I don't like it but I realize I'm in the minority here.)
author: Tristan K.

description:
Went for a lunch and ordered Unagi don which must be used sticky rice but this restaurant doesn't. Very disappointed, not sure the chef is untrained or the restaurant owner tries to fool people, or sued long grain rice that is definitely not Japanese dish. 
Order an other Sashimi "chef choice" of 8 pieces, the Sashimi is not that fresh! Lucky I didn't get food poisoning. That was a $28- dish! 
Won't not recommend to any of my friends and I won't go back. Service is OK. Overall, disappointed.
author: Erick - Masao O.

description: Rico was amazing and super friendly. I absolutely loved all the suggestions. Must try both uni if you like uni. This is probably one of the best to sushi restaurants in the Bay Area
author: Daniel C.

description: Fish was not fresh at all! I was afraid to eat a few pieces and get sick so didn't finish everything. For the price you'd have great sushi in LA. Still trying to find a decent sushi place in the city..
author: Isabella P.

description: Their chirashi (kaisendon $18) is what I normally go for lunch here. The fish is fresh-tasting and has decent quality. I asked a hot tea instead of water which is simple "ocha" you typically get without extra charge at most Japanese restaurants but they charge $4. It's not even a fancy good quality tea. Just skip the tea!
author: Jongan S.

description:
We met some friends here -- asked for a recommendation on sake, took the waiter's recommendation, and didn't realize till the bill came that he must've just picked whatever was the most expensive one.  since we'd ordered 'another round' of the same one, there was a bit of a sticker shock when perusing said bill.  

Dishes were well executed, good flavors.  but since this is supposed to be the more casual and less expensive version of Omakase (which is awesome as a special occasion place and where I EXPECT the bill to be stratospherically high!) -- it was a disappointment that we ended up dropping such a big chunk of change.  I'd go back BUT I'm not taking a sake recommendation again without LOOKING at the menu at the same time.
author: Jaina S.

description: I love Okane. The fish is incredibly fresh and the rolls are loaded with fish and other fresh ingredients. The rice is also extremely tender, so be sure to handle the rolls with care! This is a good place for people who love sushi because of the fish and are not looking for something deep fried and covered in spicy sauce. The location is pretty random but I think that's a plus, because it's not impossible to get a seat there. They also deliver on Caviar, which is awesome.
author: Abby W.

description:
I wish I could give this place 5 stars, but I can't. Everything was on point, except the food. Also it's a bit pricey for dinner.

Atmosphere: 5/5
Music: 5/5
Service: 4:5
Food: 1.5/5

The shrimp tempura gave us goosebumps. Not only that but it look like goosebump. Sukiyaki was too salty and dry.
author: Telsa K.

description: I have special dietary need and the server was neither knowledgeable about special diets nor cared to pay attention. He brought me food with ingredients I specifically said I can't eat. Good thing I'm not acutely allergic. Also overpriced! Won't come back again
author: Chiao-Yu T.

description: Enjoyed the wings (crunchy cornstarch batter),   tempura (rice cracker breading on the shrimp instead of the usual batter), seared salmon belly. They could use a wider selection of sake by the glass.
author: H S.

description: Awesome new place for a slightly different take on Japanese food! The sushi is excellent, and the concept of sharing plates ('tapas' style, if you will) is a welcome concept of you're not in the mood for the standard rice bowl or bento box. The grilled smelt and the mackerel karaage are amazing, and the salmon skin with sea urchin hand roll is the best. Servers are friendly and knowledgeable, and Jean is a good ambassador for the brand. Make a reservation now!
author: Carlo A.

description:
I had a lunch. The food was good feels very healthy and clean. But service was not very impressive. First we asked for check and the female server who was supposed to get check was taking to the other server. Well I'm fine with that she could forgot we asked. So we asked another time. Server brought the check and in the middle of writing tips, i found out that they already put 20% tip on my check. I don't want to think they did it intentionally. I understand that you want to include tip
For larger group, but at least mention it.
author: Henry K.

description: Being the sister of Omakase, I expected a bit more. The staff seemed a bit inexperienced. We ordered a sashimi dinner but got nigiri instead somehow. We decided not complain, but they should know the difference! I like that they have a bit of everything on the menu other than raw fish and rolls. The fish was fresh, and the atmosphere was on the upscale side. Perfect for a date :)
author: Mily W.

description:
Came here on a Friday night. Best service I've had in my life no joke. All the rolls have very fresh fish. The rolls have more light flavors to it versus heavy dressed sushi you may get at other places.

Staff came quickly to refill our tea and each server was very well versed in their knowledge of the sushi. Whenever they would serve our dish they would go into details of what's in the sushi. It was very nice descriptions and not awkward. I've been to other places where people have described food to me in detail and it just sounded awkward and didn't make the food sound any better.

Their last cal is generally 30 minutes before they close and what's nice about this place is that there is lots of parking!
author: Derrick C.

description:
Just had lunch here today with my 6 year-old so this review is hot and fresh!

For the price I paid for lunch, I was a little disappointed in my son's appetizer and entrees.  However, I don't remember the last time I tasted such delicious fish that it's made up for the lackluster of the other dishes.

1) 5/5 The Sushi Lunch Set came with chef's choice of 5 nigiri pieces, tekka maki (tuna roll), tamago, and miso soup.  The fish was absolute melt-in-your-mouth perfection.  At $19, I find that it's totally worth the price and was filling.

2) 2/5 The Mixed Tempura is not on the menu but I was allowed to order it anyway because what Japanese restaurant wouldn't serve tempura during lunch?  The tsuyu (tempura dipping sauce) was rather bland despite adding the grated daikon and garlic provided.  It also had a slight medicinal flavor going on which I can't say I enjoyed.  They also added popped rice into the batter for the shrimp tempura which was not my favorite either.  The vegetable tempura was not bad--green beans, asparagus, avocado, mushrooms, and I believe some kind of thin piece of root but it was so hard, I could not bite through it.  At $18, $1 less than my Sushi Lunch Set, I found this as the most overpriced appetizer I've ever encountered.  Although there were 3 pieces of shrimp and a good amount of veggies, I still don't see the justification at charging the price of an entree.  

3) 2/5 The Ontama Sukiyaki Donburi (beef donburi) was a nice and large portion, however, it was also unfortunately very bland.  Donburi is my go-to Japanese dish when ordering for my children because if they don't feel like eating the meat, they'd gladly just eat the rice with the delicious sauce.  However, my son did not enjoy it at all since it was dry and the sukiyaki beef was too chewy.  He had literally 2 bites and refused to eat anymore.  At $14, I couldn't just leave it so I took it to-go for his dad, the human-vacuum, will probably eat it for dinner later with no problem.

4) 5/5 Service was awesome.  The servers were very nice, prompt, and checked on us consistently.  It was definitely full table service which is a nice surprise since most typical Japanese lunch spots have servers who are focused on rushing out orders rather than focusing on their customers. 

5) 5/5 Cleanliness/Decor was totally my style.  Very chic and appropriate decor that was not too busy or distracting.  I couldn't help but notice how nice their wooden chopsticks were as well as the dishware.  Yes, little things like this deserve mention when reviewing a restaurant.  They do make a difference in my dining experience and it's much appreciated when a restaurant takes that much care in choosing such small details.

I am definitely coming back here for lunch when craving some good sashimi.  I would still try out their other entrees in the future but I really do hope that the restaurant will revamp their donburi sauce.
author: Ivy Z.

description: Sashimi is great. Tuna really melts in your mouth. Ordered 3 different rolls, asakusa, ginza, and raponggi, they are all good. Even plain udon was great. Grilled shitake is so so, wing karaage is tasty. Service is slooow. Ordered gari/ginger and it didn't come. Second round of ordering finally got us a plate.
author: Linda D.

description:
Personally I really love salmon and Okane is my new go to fix. 

Salmon Alburi- delicious pieces of salmon wrapped around fatty avocado topped with ikura.  YUM! While also being very aesthetically pleasing to the eye. 

Sake belly- very fresh sashimi with a butter like texture. 

Akihabara- my favorite roll topped with unagi centered with salmon (of course) and avocado. 

Apart from the salmon, Okane has very unique ippin options that are very worth trying out.
