Spinach with Sesame mouse- mashed sesame that is prepared like a pastry roll with a house made sesame sauce. Never had anything like it , but was definitely unique and tasty ! 

Agedashi tofu- a breaded tofu that comes in a fish based sauce served in a clay pot, very light and flavorful ! 

So glad I found Okane and will be back lots !
author: Shaylene L.

description:
I came here on a lightly crowded Valentines Day because I had heard that it was the sister restaurant to the fancy Omakase restaurant next door. Apparently, the same people who pick out the fish at Omakase also pick out the fish for Okane... good enough for me! We started the night off with the chef's oysters, which were absolutely divine. 6 oysters came out on ice, each with quail egg, uni, tomiko and ikura (flying fish/salmon egg), and a light drizzling of ponzu sauce. Seriously, perfect. 

Although it wasn't listed on the menu, we were told that we could still order the omakase (chef's choice)  for a set price of 80 bucks. The price is a little cheaper than the average SF sushi place, I think.

The first course that we got was the ankimo (monkfish liver) in ponzu sauce.  It came in 3 hearty portions of ankimo; I'm not generally a fan of ankimo, but the ponzu sauce that the ankimo came with was fantastic. The next dish we got was two large pieces of salmon belly and two pieces of maguro (tuna) sashimi. Both my date and I commented on how fresh and soft the fish was in comparison to some other places that give out sinewy, poorly cut pieces that you could tell have been frozen. The next 11 pieces that we got were all nigiri; nothing overly exotic: fatty tuna (almost literally melted in your mouth), Hamachi tuna, halibut, albacore,  Hokkaido scallop, squid, makarel, salmon, uni, unagi, and wagyu (given free courtesy of the chef!). The end of the meal ended with the option of tamago or black sesame ice cream. The black sesame ice cream was absolutely amazing, and a perfect ending to the meal.

I normally like to liberally drown my sushi in soy sauce because 1) I love soy sauce  2) I'm an uncultured swine, but I will begrudgingly admit that the sushi was so perfect that nothing required soy sauce. The wagyu (some places don't season it properly, cook it too much, add too much other crap, but this piece was perfectly fat and cooked) and the chef's oysters honestly were so good that I was left speechless for a few minutes.

Sample Conversation:
Her: "Hey, these are reall-"
Me: "I need a minute"
Her: "Oh come o-"
Me: -audible moan-

Definitely come here and try it out!
author: Kevin Z.

description:
Had high expectations for this place, but was a bit disappointed. Had reservations and the hostess sat us at a table with this tiny chairs with no backing. Later on I asked the manager to move to a bigger table with a booth seating. So much more comfortable. Our waitress was very friendly, but she messed up on our order twice....she wrote everything down and repeated our order so not sure how she can still mess up.

The food started off pretty good, than it got worse and we were over it. Pretty large selection of stuff to choose from. 

Fried lotus root chips-these were good and I love anything fried

Assorted chicken skewers-the size of these were pretty big, tender, and flavorful

Chicken wings with spicy mayo and shiso salt-perfectly fried and the shiso salt made it very yummy

Beef tataki with ponzu gelee-looked amazing, but super bland. 

Salmon and ikura chazuke with a tea soup-bland, bland, bland. We had to put some soy sauce to make it taste better

Salmon and avocado-it was part of their special fish. It looks like salmon sashimi wrapped around avocado. Not sure what was so special about this

The ankimo was really good. We ordered a few nigiris and sashimi pieces came out instead. We told our waitress so the rest of wouldn't be a mistake. The sashimi was only ok. Nothing special. Not bad, but not super fresh. They also ran out of alot of things. 

We ordered 2 rolls, but only received one. Snow crab, avocado, topped with A5 wagu beef, fired garlic, and sancho pepper-first you can't put A5 wagu beef on the menu if that's not what you are serving. It was tough and so bland. Isn't this suppose to melt in your mouth? SMH.
The waitress forgot the to put in the other roll. We were too full and didn't want it anymore since we knew it was going to be bland anyways. Need to work out some kinks still and improve on the flavor of their food.
author: Karen H.

description: Okane, sister restaurant to Omakase, serves homey Japanese food in an upscale setting. My boyfriend and I came in for lunch, hoping for some friendlier prices, but be warned that the lunch menu is still relatively expensive. I had the chicken teriyaki bento, which came with salad, an assortment of pickled veggies, and rice. The chicken reminded me of home, not at all like the sticky sweet teriyaki you would think of. The portions were just right to keep me full but not feel overstuffed. My boyfriend had the beef sukiyaki, which came in a claypot with an assortment of veggies and meat in a flavorful broth. We also tried the agedashi tofu and chawanmushi, both of which were cooked perfectly. My only complaint would be that both were slightly lacking in salt. All in all, it felt like a fancy home-cooked meal, and I'd definitely come back again.
author: Ashley T.

description:
I was surprised their food was really underwhelming considering it's managed by the same people as Omakase.

Our waiter was really sweet and nice, but the food was so disappointing.
author: EriCardo F.

description:
Really bad tamago, which in my experience, is usually a key indicator as to how the rest of the meal is going to go. We had hoped for the best, but it was cold, had the consistency of well-done cheesecake and essentially, flavorless.

The pickle plate (a tablespoon of daikon) with white rice/nori = 50 cents worth of food for $7.

The bok choy with sesame sauce was entirely forgettable, unless you count the plating, which looked like a plop of runny hummus dropped on the plate.

The saba karaage was decent, as was some of the nigiri (one piece of hotate was super stringy).

They overcharged us on our bill (which we caught), but we just spent $100 without ordering a cocktail. I can't imagine what the people next door are paying.

This was most certainly a design district meal.
author: Justin H.

description: Excellent quality fish! Tried hamachi nigiri, salmon tartar-all highly recommended. Also nice lounge music and pleasant atmosphere, great place for a nice evening date or outing if you want a cozy place to enjoy nice sushi and chat.
author: Irina E.

description: Loved this place! We came here Saturday evening of July 4th weekend around 7 PM and were seated immediately without a reservation. It was not super crowded, but had a good amount of people inside. We got the Chicken Karaage, Hokkaido Uni, Shinjuku Roll, and Beef Sukiyaki. The sukiyaki was good at first, but once you eat more, is a bit too salty. The karaage was really tender on the inside and crispy on the outside, and the Hokkaido uni was really good as well--it tasted super fresh! But the Shinjuku was definitely the highlight. The wagyu beef on top was perfect: slightly smokey, great flavor. Really high quality sushi for a non-ridiculous price. It makes me curious what the sister restaurant next door (Omakase) is like!
author: Stephanie H.

description: This place is amazing! The place is  beautiful, the artwork  is tasteful, and the place just wants you to make you want to stay there... As if you are visiting a family member'splace. The food is amazing too! The tuna belly, the a5 wagu beef  roll, and the cod sake grilled I can't get enough of! This place is amazing! I can't wait to go back!!!
author: Joel V.

description:
Okane translated is money. So.. Know what you are getting yourself into. I ordered: 

Toro nigiri
Hamachi nigiri
Sea urchin nigiri
Salmon sashimi
Ocha

I ate it without soy sauce. That says a lot about this place. It's fresh. It's good.

Don't complain about rolls or condiments. You want to come here for a small taste of Japan-- not for a white wash Japanese food that drizzle mayo or spicy mayo all over the rolls and deep fried everything in pork fat. 

If so, buy yourself a bottle of mayo and shiracha ... mix it, and add some fish from vons-- voila! I just saved you $50. You are welcome!
author: Nit A.

description:
I thought Live Sushi was as good as it gets, but it gets better! My friends and I came here for dinner and ordered up a storm. Highly recommend the Ginza and Wagyu Beef Roll in which we ordered double of. The Wagyu Beef Roll's price ($25) jumped out at me, but c'mon its Wagyu! 

Agedashi tofu, udon noodles, and shiso rice dishes were delish. I loved that the water and tea kept coming and kept our table very hydrated. Super friendly service and easy parking. We even had our two year old, so totally family friendly. Okane, we will be back.
author: Betty H.

description: Came Here on a Tuesday night around 730 without reservations and got sat quickly! My boyfriend and I ordered a bunch of nigiri,beef sukiyaki, chawamushi and I got to say everything hit the spot. Food was coursed out perfectly and we left happily and full! The fish was very fresh and everyone was very friendly. Loved the atmosphere and music choice. They were playing Upbeat edm music, which made dinner a lot more lively! Without a doubt, I would definitely come back and try everything else on the menu!!! Thank you Okane!
author: Angela H.

description: If you're into quality Japanese food, this is the spot. It's a little pricier than other Japanese places, but it's all worth it. I like to come here for lunch to get the bento boxes and other traditional Japanese cuisines. The food is great and the customer service is great. TRY THIS PLACE!
author: Jenn C.

description:
Stopped by in here for lunch and we started with an order of the sushi lunch set. Ours came with a tamago, hamachi, salmon, kuromaguro, and one more that I can't remember. All were good and higher quality than other sushi places I've been to in SF. 

We decided to then order the Yu-dofu which was a little bitter and a good tofu-based broth to sip on while we waited for our nigiri orders.

We ordered the Unagi and Hokkaido Uni nigiris with Toro sashimi. All of them were delicious. The toro was a higher quality cut that looked marbled and tasted like meat. Price-wise it's extremely good. Sanraku charges about $14 for a 2-piece nigiri of toro that is definitely low quality. $18 here at Okane is worth it if you've never had toro like this before.

Extremely friendly wait-staff. If you want the same quality of cuts as Omakase but on a budget, then this is the place for you. We came out to $55/person (pre-tip) for an awesome sushi lunch.
author: Eric H.

description: Came here for brunch. They have new items , really good! Tried the miyabi and mergumi. Both were great. Also ban ryu sake is very good
author: Jones T.

description: I ordered a chicken teriyaki bento box for lunch and they brought me the most minuscule amount of chicken and rice imaginable. They should have provided me a magnifying glass to locate the chicken on the plate. The chicken also tasted like mystery meat/ expired rat. There was a side of some sort of spinach salad that tasted like dirt or something found in a swamp. I left Okane starving and full of disappointment.
author: Brandon M.

description:
Had dinner tonight with the girlfriend at Okane and loved it! We are big fans of Omakase so wanted to give the sister restaurant a try.

The izakaya-style food was fairly traditional and comparable to what I had in Tokyo recently. The sukiyaki is a rarity in SF - great balance of flavors without being overly salty. Highly recommend having it with a bowl of Japanese rice! The clam and oyster pot was also cooked to perfection. Both were very tender and fresh, paired with a light, delicious dashi. We also enjoyed the sushi very much - reasonably priced for great quality.

If I had to nit pick, wished the sushi bar was a bit bigger so I can get a reservation easier!
author: Raymond S.

description: Insanely delicious sushi! And amazing customer service! Cindy is my absolute favorite and she seems to always keep her cool and keep everyone happy even when it's super busy. I've never been annoyed waiting for a table on busy nights.
author: Grace B.

description:
Okane is a welcomed addition to the Japanese food scene in SF! One thing I miss about NYC is the many casual izakayas for some Japanese cooked dishes. Surprise - I'm not always craving sushi though SF has plenty of solid options these days (Omakase, the sister restaurant is fantastic).

Been here a few times now. Always consistent food and service. A few favorites - Saba karaage, sukiyaki, steamed oysters & clams. 

Will be back!
author: Angel L.

description:
Visited Okane for dinner on a Saturday for a friend's birthday party. The location isn't the most accessible in SF, but the food and atmosphere really makes up for it. 

1. The Lotus Chips are crispy, and lightly-seasoned in wasabi. Pairs very well with the mayo-ish condiment.
2. We shared had a about half a dozen of maki rolls, and the Roppongi stood out. I never had anything like that before, thinly shaved cucumber used as a wrapper for the maki roll. It gave a very light and refreshing touch to the maki. Both Shibuya and Kappabashi are top-notched and well-balanced makis. The salmon (shibuya) and BF tuna (kappabashi) are fresh and melts in the mouth.
3. The beef tataki was tender and very well paired with the ponzu.
author: Lee-Hong L.

description:
We got a coupon of complementary drinks and appetizer, so we decided to check it out. :)
The sushi was amazing, mouth watering and very filling!

We ordered the Mackerel Dish and it was delicious. Would definitely go there again and again!
author: Tejal D.

description: The Brunch is exquisite. Presentation is rustic and refined. The service is attentive but not stuffy. The cocktails are inventive. And my egg was perfect. Go.
author: Kate L.

description:
Inconvenient location. Solid food. 

I was surprised by the quality of their dishes here. And then I learned that they share the supplier with the Michelin star rated Omakase next door. #winning 

My friend and I made the mistake of walking into Omakase like two bozos before finding out Okane was one door down. Note Omakase is tiny, dimly lit, quiet, and most likely reservations-only.. 

"Uh... Can we get a table for two?"
"Do you have a reservation" 
"No.. Is this Okane?"

A friendly Japanese female server kindly let us know Okane is one door down.

Apologies for the disruption, fine diners.

When we got to Okane, it couldn't have been more different than Omakase. Bright, no smell of a Michelin star, people eating mostly rolls. Well, the meal was theirs to lose after THAT resetting of expectation! 

Im happy to say Okane completely delivered and exceeded far exceeded our drastically lowered  expectation. Our server was extremely knowledgeable about the menu - a huge plus given I brushed him off in my mind at first for being a white dude. My bad.


Chicken karaage - 3.5 stars. Deliciously crispy, well seasoned, a little too oily for me 

Mackerel karaage - 4 stars. Quality fish not over cooked. Nicely balanced with the grated daikon and jalapeño mixture

Bok choy with sesame sauce - 4 stars. Perfectly cooked bok choy and delicious sesame sauce. We ended up asking for more bok choy because there was way more sauce than bok choy

Hamachi sashimi - 4 stars. Fresh. High quality, buttery sashimi. No real wasabi though

Shinjuku roll - 5 stars. This was for sure the highlight of the meal. Real crab meat and avocado roll topped with AMAZING pieces of seared wagyu beef. Melted in my mouth. I'd go back just for this roll. Note this is a pricey dish ($25). The server let us know the beef is sourced from the same supplier that Omakase uses. I always judge roll eaters but damn, I'm all in for this one. Yummmmm


I'd definitely go back to try other dishes and get the roll again and judge the shit out of myself.
author: Michelle K.

description:
I like Izakaya in general so I went check this place out with my friend on my day off.
From a native Japanese standpoint, all the dishes were little too big but that's probably just me. Sashimi fish here were incredibly fresh, the server told me they source their fish from Tsukiji..makes sense!

Saba karaage? I've been to many Japanese restaurant and have never heard of anyone deep frying Saba, so I gave it a try and both presentation and taste was great.

Shrimp arare tempura? The tempura was huge, which is good because we were hungry. Arare rice cracker gave it some unique and distinct texture to it, avocado tempura threw me off first but taste was actually great.

Ocean trout sashimi was one of their special so we gave it a shot. Sashimi was thick and tasted amazing. I believe they put truffle oil on them. We ordered few other sashimi and they were all much better quality than what I've had in many other restaurants. Menu had some fish I've never seen in other places too.

OKANE HANDROLL was out of this world, a must try if you're into uni. It's basically a handroll with sea urchin, salmon roe and shiso leaf and salmon skin? Such a great idea for a handroll!! Little pricey for a handroll but I ordered a second one after eating the first one, just take my money!

With a bottle of small sake, bill came out to about $150 for 2 people, not too bad for the experience, we ate a lot of food.

Overall I'd like to give this place a 5 star.
Service is good.
Food is great.
Atmosphere is good.
And lastly, their black sesame ice cream.. was crazy good.
author: Mario K.

description: Just found my new lunch place near work. This place is amazing! There service was on point and their food was delicious. I highly recommend trying the Wagyu Beef Roll and the Ginza Roll. You won't be disappointed. I'll admit I was a little hesitate at first because you don't know what to expect from a new place. But I'm happy to say, I was very pleased.
author: Priscilla C.

description: The grilled cod and Hamchi Kami were really good! We also got the deep fried lotus chips, Akihabara roll and chicken karaage. All quite good and would definitely recommend ordering them again. We finished of the meal with Uni nigiri and Ikura nigiri. We liked the Uni much better and it was worth the price of $10 for the pair. The Ikura was a bit salty and not as fresh as it could be. They also have delicious drinks like melon soda ramune and Yuri masa muni sake!
author: Kenny L.

description:
Nothing gets me more excited than trying a new Japanese restaurant in the city. My friend and I decided to come in on a Friday night for dinner and we were not disappointed :) Being a sister restaurant of Omakase, I would definitely come here if you were looking for a more casual/chill compared to Omakase's upscale vibe. We sat at the bar and I'm so glad we did! 

For nigiri, my friend and I ordered the toro and sake belly which were both delicious. The fatty tuna melted in my mouth as expected. We also ordered the Ginza and Shinjuku roll but the one that stood out more was the Shinjuku roll which had snow crab, avo, and torched A5 wagyu. Who doesn't love wagyu?!  

The chef at the bar recommended to us try Hakkaku (sailfin poacher) which was a fish I've never heard of before. It's a three course set that prepares the Hakkaku three ways. Since he said it was their special of the day, we decided to give it a try. The first course was a beautifully presented sashimi platter of Hakkaku along with the body of the fish. It came with about 15 pieces which was a pretty good amount for the two of us. The second course was the crispy skin of the fish which I thought tasted like chips! And lastly, we ended the meal with a fish broth soup which was soooo yummy! There were fish bones, tofu and all these different herbs in it. We were super stuffed, but our chef gave us tamago and their homemade white sesame ice cream on the house! I've never had white sesame ice cream before but it was honestly the best sesame ice cream I've ever had. I realized as I was biting into their tamago that it's the same one that Omakase serves as well! Overall, I had a great meal at Okane and I can't wait to be back. 

Tip: You can order dishes from Omakase at Okane, super plus!
author: Elisa S.

description:
Finally, a well designed Japanese restaurant with atmosphere.
Plus the service is impeccable!!!!
The menu is small and unique..
Everything we tried was fresh, delicious, surprising and beautifully presented on gorgeous Japanese ceramics.
author: Dagmar W.

description:
Okane (Japanese) on SF Townsend Street is excellent.

My 2 friends and I ate dinner last Friday. The food was excellent. The waitress was quite helpful and attentive. The price with tax was about $32 per person without alcohol. 

Okane is small and with street parking. The restaurant is designed to order multiple foods and share with your friends, but going alone is OK, as well.

We had the following: bok chow with a seasoning dip sauce that was superb, chicken skewers that were tasty and tender, scallop sashimi, and shrimp tempura rolls. Each of these was excellent. Also, we had green tea and ice cream; both were good.

The only downside was that the bill overcharged us a lot for the scallop sashimi and that is inexcusable; however they adjusted the price.

Yes, I will return to Okane in SF.
author: Robert H.

description:
Very convenient at night because usually there is always availabilities.
Nice service and correct food. Not cheap though...
author: Stephane R.

description:
I'm still dreaming about the Ginza Roll which has everything you could ever want rolled in a sushi roll, (avocado, shrimp tempera, cucumber, topped with torched hamachi, jalapeno and blue fin tuna). please keep them coming!

Okane... the food was fresh, the place was beautiful, and the staff were all extremely attentive and friendly. i was super dehydrated before i arrived and my water glass was never empty! 

some other highlights for me were the grilled sake lees cured alaskan cod, the agedashi tofu and the shinjuku roll (sushi topped with A5 wagyu)! the taste buds were overjoyed! i cannot wait to go back!
author: Jackie L.

description: We went there for our wedding anniversary.  Fresh fish, great service, good ambience.  Only gripe was that they had no desert selection.
author: Sandeep B.

description:
Okane is a great addition to our neighborhood and I look forward to many more killer meals here!
The food is very good, especially the Ginza roll, the staff is friendly and efficient, and there are many great wines and sake to enjoy accordingly!
author: Peter M.

description: Fantastic sushi and unique rolls, appetizers, and dishes. Great service!  Highly recommend the Ginza and Harajuku rolls and the salmon and avocado dish.
author: Greg and Ann P.

description: Sashimi was wonderful but Beef roll was disappointing. Overall go for sashimi, really empty when we went. Not sure why. Suppose to be the sister company of omakase next store. Walked into wrong restaurant, the staff walked me over. Nice people
author: Tiff W.

description: On a visit to SFO we looked on Yelp for restaurants near the place we rented for the weekend.  Okane got 4 stars and was relatively close so we headed out.  The menu is eclectic, meaning it was pretty hard to understand. We saw some recognizable words, but the descriprions tried to be too fancy/traditional. The service was slow and to make matters worse our server disappeared after taking our order. The food runners brought out the food, but when I needed another beer and a few more items she was no where to be seen. Then she appeared with her bag on her shoulder, punched out on the computer and walked right past us and out the door without a word. Last but not least, the food. We ordered 6 items and only one item was good, the Karaage chicken was really good. The tempura bad, the beef skewers had no taste, the agedashi tofu was actually tofu tempura, yuck. The nigiri sushi, weak. And I wont even expand on thier "craft beer" from japan. All I wanted was a large Sapporo. Okane, never again. Sayonara!
author: Owen I.

description: Quality sushi. I had a minor issue with delivery and their general manager took care of me with class.
author: R G.

description: We had a great ladies night here, the food is so delicious and service is great! The manager ordered everything for us and we tried all different appetizer, sushi, Fred Chicken and cod fish! Definitely will go back again!
author: Lin T.

description: We went here for lunch today with a colleague. I got chicken karaage bento box. The chicken felt like I was chewing on cartilage. The rice was good. The miso was ok. I don't put one star because they didn't make me pay for the bento box from which I only ate the rice, fair.
author: Leo W.

description:
Since the first time I came to this restaurant two months ago, I've been back several times, bringing different friends or relatives. 
The food is delicate and never overly seasoned. Ingredients are always fresh and of good quality. My must haves at every visit are the chawanmushu and the home made sesame ice cream. Delicious!
author: montreal g.

description: Overall, an A-OK experience with some big hits and misses. The sushi and chawanmushi were excellent. However, the Yu-doufu was cold in the center and completely lacking in flavor and the agedashi tofu was rather bland as well--avoid! The udon was pretty good but not too memorable.
author: Jia H.

description: I am so happy that I found this restaurant! The Shinjuku roll and Beef sukiyak are must-try! The mackerel Bento Box is not bad. All dishes were served in relatively small sizes, but they are so delicious and thats enough!
author: Vicky L.

description:
*Food isnt that great and over priced*
Nigiris: uni and toro was good 
Rolls: too much rice and didnt not taste good - do not recommend rolls

Price should be $$$ and this place over all wasnt that good
author: Peetas M.

description: Came here, was impressed with the food and small details of the restaurant. Food is tasty and fresh, will be going here again to try more things.
author: Sharon P.

description: By far some of the best sushi, fish & Japanese cuisine we have ever eaten. Everything from the fresh nigiri, to the cauliflower risotto, the chicken wings and everything else we tried was just superb. Even my husband who isn't a fish eater tried & loved everything he ate! The service was amazing and the owner (Cash) is one of the nicest people we have ever met.  We can't wait to go back! And to try Cash's other restaurants. Thank you so much for an amazing evening full of great food, great friends & lots of fun.
author: Erin B.

description: I'd give ten stars if I could!! Hip spot, great tunes, AMAZING, fresh and delicious food complimented by super attentive staff. Thanks to Ian, Barry and company,  we felt like royalty. Hats  off to the new GM Justin for producing an all around hit. Can't wait to go back and treat myself to some badass izakaya.
author: El M.

description: walked in, was seated then was ignored for 10 minutes. With so many overpriced sushi joints to pick from, why deal with this.
author: Rharrison79 ..

description: Incredible. Amazing nigiris and sashimis. Music was too loud but the food made up for it
author: Pau Y Monica C.

description:
Decent food, but I would not come back due to price and better options for similar cuisine in the neighborhood.  

My boyfriend and I shared 4 dishes (noodles, a roll, karaage, and clams).  We were far from full, but decided to finish dinner elsewhere.  

Food was overall well done (a bit oversweet/oversalty for delicate japanese food), but I have one MAJOR complaint, which was that they only served us one dish at a time, and then we had to wait between dishes.  Due to this schedule, they were also extremely rushed to clear our food.  They would try to take our plates away even when we were still eating, with chopsticks still in the bowl!  We felt extremely rushed by the multiple servers trying to clear our plates every time they walked by.  We had ordered some dishes that would have paired well together since one was over salty (i.e. the karaage with the noodles), but couldn't do that.
author: T Y.

description: In search of some real Japanese food, as Ive been in europe for almost a year. I wandered around my area during my lunch and hit a jackpot. Ambiance when I walked in was cozy and welcoming. The service was great and the food was just what I needed. I had some amazing and fresh sashimi which hit the spot. My only issue was parking, which wasnt horrible if you don't mind a walk or searching the streets. Other than that, I'll be coming back with my colleagues real soon.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
i love this place!
they have a great playlist, such a chill place too
the best ankimo ive had in the USA!
they have karaage but not any ordinary karaage...its mackerel and oh so good!
the sushi is great quality and the sake list is pretty descent.
cant wait to go back!
author: Marie r.

description: Amazing food, amazing service and not overpriced. Been a few times and absolutely loved it!! The black cod appetizer is to die for and fresh fish variety is very good. Knowledgeable and very friendly staff with good sake selection. I would give them 6 stars if I could :) Highly recommend this place!!!
author: Galina R.

description:
I went to Okane with several friends from SF and NYC hoping for a fun casual dinner and we were not let down. The fish here is extremely fresh and delicious and the small plates were great. The karaage is a must try. We split one plate and ended up ordering 2 more. The grilled shiitakes were also really good.

Our favorite sushi were the various bellies - toro, salmon belly (special that night), one other I forget. They were out of aji, but had shima-aji which was just as delicious. The ginza and shinjuku rolls are great. The toched A5 on the shinjuku is just as extravagant as it sounds. We also had the harajuku and asakusa which were great, but I'm sure any of them would be great. The fish is fresh and the combinations go well.

They have a good sake list and we tried a few different bottles which our server recommended. When someone said they wanted nigori, she guided us to a not-too sweet one which really hit the spot.

Other things: easy to get to, ample parking, 90s hip-hop playing non-stop. Its a fun spot with good food, will definitely be back.
author: Derek P.

description: Been here 4 times. Service sucked all 4 times. Slow delivery, slow follow up. Sushi expensive but above average quality. Not so friendly staff. I'll only come again if others are willing to pay the bill.
author: Karma Is Coming 4 U.

description: My dinner there was mediocre at best.  Even though they are a sister restaurant to Omakase next door, the quality of the fish and the sushi/sashimi preparation are nowhere close.  The other items: soup, salads, cooked fish, are likewise entirely uninspired.  Many better choices in SF for Japanese.
author: Alex S.

description: Overall it's good. Nice service. One thing is that the rice is quite pricey. $7 for one rice.
author: Nacy V.

description: Dinner is great but lunch service and food are poor. Waitress got order wrong and was inattentive all meal, and food was way too salty. Also lunch menu is really expensive for portion size.
author: Tony D.

description: What a great lunch addition to the neighborhood.  Fresh, innovative, and delicious.  The Grilled Sake Lees Cured Alaskan Cod and Roppongi and Harakuku Rolls are quite tasty... especially when washed down with one of their many sake's.  I would highly recommend.
author: Matt S.

description: My friend and I decided to try this spin-off of Omikase on a weekday night, and we both ordered the chef's sashimi sampler.  The fish quality was just ok - some pieces tasted fine, while others were not so fresh.  I thought it was maybe just me, but my friend felt the same way.  As a chef's choice sampler, the chef can choose whatever cuts of fish he would like to serve.  Given that he chose to serve fish that wasn't that fresh is disappointing. In addition, a bowl of rice was not included and was an additional five dollars.  Hence, two stars.
author: Eric W.

description: Very good sushi. We mainly have their delivery through Caviar. From the Agedashi Tofu to their sushi rolls - excellent. We ate their once in person and thought the service was mediocre but the chef is fantastic. The service is the only reason I did not give it a 5 star. Maybe it was just that day, but the servers and host were confused and kind of disorganized. The food made up for it.
author: Faisal M.

description: Wish I could review them since my company just opened up across the street AND I've been to Omakase. I called to order something for lunch and they had some overly complex reason as to why I can't place an order and would need to dine in instead despite being stated as having take out as an option on Yelp. Very disappointing, overly complicated - I'll take my business elsewhere.
author: Elisabeth H.

description: My husband and I ate here during the soft opening. We shared a lot of small dishes and some sushi rolls and I ordered the Udon for my main which was delicious. It was just what I wanted. My husband ordered a rice dish that he really liked that had shiso in it (I don't remember the name). The staff was friendly and knowledgeable. We will be back!
author: Marie Y.

description: Recently came here for Dinner and all I have to say is that it was delicious!!  Wonderful service and outstanding food!! They're known for their small items like the Salmon Aburi and Shimofuri Hamachi! Both were amazing! Our server Dana was very helpful when it came to the menu as well!! I'll definitely be back!!!!
author: Lisa L.

description: Tried two of their specialty rolls and they were both great. The food was all fresh, the place is clean, feels upscale, and the servers are nice. I was able to walk in around 6 on a Friday and just sat at the 5 seat sushi bar alone with some tables open. It got a little busy afterwards and most people had reservations.  Will definitely come back.
author: daniel h.

description: I was really pleasantly surprised by this restaurant. I came here for dinner with another person on a Monday night and the restaurant was mostly full, but wasn't too crowded and we were seated right away. The service was attentive and pleasant right off the bat. The server brought water and told us the specials and took our order, then brought sushi garnishes in pretty little plates to the table (the usual stuff: soy sauce, pickled ginger, and wasabi). We ordered three dishes- the hamachi kama (sp?), which turned out to be a collar of hamachi grilled and served with ponzu, the harajuku roll, and the chicken karaage. All were attractive and pretty delicious. The details were done right- the hamachi was seasoned into the crevices and tasted like it was grilled over charcoal, the karaage was very very hot and fresh, and the harajuku roll had a lot of accents that didn't feel gimmicky (the lotus root chips on top were seasoned and spicy and were a really delicious garnish).  Portions felt a little light for the price (50$ for a light dinner for 2 people, no beverages), but not unreasonable.
author: Allison W.

description: I went to dinner here with a coworker of mine and it was amazing. Very fair priced plates (especially for the same expertise from the owner of the Michelin Starred Omakase). The owner/head chef Jackson came out and made sure our meals were to satisfaction and that we were enjoying our time. Really cool atmosphere and super friendly wait staff, I will definitely be coming back.
author: Stevie J.

description: I had the pleasure to try some items from the menu during the soft opening. The Alaskan Cod and the Tuna belly were absolutely delicious! Thumbs up to everyone for great ambiance! Gibb and Ian, way to go! :)
author: Tom M.
